Camellia krempfii, C. dormoyana, C. fleuryi and C. langbianensis are native to the southern provinces of Viet Nam. The past and recent paucity of live materials appears to be the consequence of the destruction of historically documented native habitats. The ongoing land clearing  causing the demise of native vegetation appears to be the result of the ever rising population and its demands for acceptable living conditions.
Despite a decade long effort by a group of international and Australian scientists and collectors, the reliable documentation of the locations of wild populations of these Camellia species has remained elusive. Mis-identification of some taxa in National Parks and in some private collections, e.g. Camellia krempfii (Gagnep.) Sealy and C. dormoyana (Pierre ex Laness) Sealy has occurred.

Podocarpus spathoides was originally described in 1985 based on specimens collected from near the summit of Gunung Ledang (1,276 m a.s.l.) in Malaysia. Farjon (2010) gave its distribution as Peninsular Malaysia, Sarawak, Morotai, the Rossel Islands southeast of Papua New Guinea and the Solomon Islands. De Laubenfels (1988) noted that collections from the Solomons could represent another taxon. Silba (2000) described these collections under the name P. spathoides var. solomonensis. Following recent field work in the Solomons and utilizing new herbarium collections, Mill and Whiting (2012) redescribed Silba's taxon as a distinct species (P. orarius) unrelated to P. spathoides. They also reviewed the collections from Indonesia and Papua New Guinea that had previously been identified as P. spathoides and concluded that all these specimens represented species other than P. spathoides. Specimens from Sarawak were not examined. As a consequence of this new research P. spathoides is now regarded as endemic to Peninsular Malaysia and possibly Sarawak.

Podocarpus subtropicalis has been identified with P. neriifolius by Chinese botanists (see Flora of China 4: 82, 1999), although it is usually not explicitly synonymized with that species in the recent floristic literature. Its taxonomic status remains somewhat uncertain and is not helped by the circumstance that it seems to have been widely spread in cultivation. Its morphology is also close to P. fasciculus, a species from Taiwan described by de Laubenfels (1985) in the same paper on the same page, both with short Latin descriptions and type designations, but without comparative discussion. A more critical taxonomic comparison based on further sampling from trees occurring in the wild is needed.

The genus Tozzia is a systematically relatively isolated plant group, including only two closely related species: T. alpina and T. carpathica, evaluated by some authors as two subspecies within a single species. Their geographic range does not overlap: T. alpina occurs in montane zones from the Pyrenees to the western part of former Yugoslavia, T. carpathica is distributed in the Carpathians and in the southern Balkan mountains.

Galanthus elwesii is often confused with G. gracilis, as both of these species have glaucous leaves and two green marks (or one very large green mark) on each inner perianth segment, and they can occur in similar localities and populations. Galanthus gracilis and G. elwesii are closely related, but they can be easily distinguished from one another by the type of vernation (the position of the leaves when they are in bud), which is applanate (leaves flat against each other) and supervolute (one leaf encircling the other), respectively. Other distinguishing characteristics, which are reliable but not totally discrete for each species, are the width of the leaves and the general dimensions of the plant: G. gracilis usually has narrow leaves and is generally of smaller dimensions than G. elwesii. The leaves of G. gracilis are frequently twisted but they can also be straight. Molecular data (Lledo et al. 2004, Larsen et al. 2010) infers that these two species are distinct.

The confusion between G. elwesii and G. gracilis is especially critical in their European ranges, and at the present time their exact distributions are poorly understood. Molecular studies are currently being undertaken with the aim of addressing these problems and questions concerning species delimitation.

There is some dispute about the taxonomic status of Crambe koktebelica (Junge) N. Busch. Kotov (1979) proposed that C. koktebelica is a species with a Crimean–Caucasian distribution and that C. mitridatis is endemic to Crimea. However, the authors of the second and third editions of the Red Data Book of Ukraine (Schelag-Soconko 1996, Diduch 2009) consider C. koktebelica as endemic to Crimea, while C. mitridatis is a Crimean–Caucasian species. Chalilov (1993) regarded C. koktebelica and C. mitridatis as a single species and published C. koktebelica as a valid species with C. mitridatis as a synonym.

The species is a wild relative of the oil producing and fodder crop, C. abyssinica R.E. Fr., as well as being related to other brassica crops as a member of the subtribe Brassicinae (tribe Brassiceae) (Maxted et al. in prep.).

The World Checklist of Selected Plant Families (The Board of Trustees of the Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew 2010) treats Ceratophyllum tanaiticum as a synonym of C. muricatum ssp. muricatum. Unfortunately this disagrees with most other authors (e.g., Les 1985; Cook 1996, 2004; Tzvelev 1996; Fu and Les 2001) and only serves to obscure information on C. tanaiticum to the extent that it is difficult to establish its distribution and status.

As with other members of the genus, there is a need for taxonomic clarification and this confusion could obscure the actual distribution and status of taxa.

The genus Utricularia is taxonomically complex, partly due to the desire of botanists to establish methods of identifying non-flowering populations (particularly in the field), with the consequence that the literature is complicated by vast numbers of unreliable records. Many taxa rarely flower and some have apparently never been known to flower in some regions. The majority of the data presented here is derived from Taylor (1989) which is the most reliable source. Additional information has been used where it is felt that it is both useful and reliable.

It is possible that U. bremii does not reproduce sexually and is a vegetative apomict (Taylor 1989).

It has been shown that not only are some populations of Ranunculus subgenus Batrachium composed of complexes of polyploid clones attributable to a single taxon, but that other populations may be composed more or less entirely of hybrid combinations involving up to three parents and indistinguishable from each other or unhybridised plants without molecular analysis (Lansdown 2007). Several current and conflicting taxonomies (Castroviejo et al. 1986, Stace 1997, Jonsell 2000, Rothmaler 2005, van der Meijden 2005) co-exist and are applied in differing ways in Europe and it is clear from published information that both the identification guidance and recording are inconsistent between countries, regions and taxa.

Assessment of the taxa “most widely recognised” against the Red List Criteria is, at best, hopeful and an attempt has been made to explain any conclusions reached. Distribution data are mainly derived from the only truly critical account (Cook 1966) although it is clear that even that includes some inaccuracies. The exceptions to this are R. circinatus and R. hederaceus which may, at times, be misidentified but are taxonomically discrete.

Beta hybrida Andrz. is recorded as an accepted species by Euro+Med PlantBase (2006) which currently forms the taxonomic core of the CWR Catalogue for Europe and the Mediterranean (Kell et al. 2005) for the Chenopodiaceae family. V. Melnyk (pers. comm. 2010) notes that the species was described by A. Andrjejevski in 1862 but that it has not been recorded since. Morphological characters of B. hybrida correspond with those of B. trigyna, described by Waldstein et Kitaibel in 1802 and in the Flora of Ukraine, B. hybrida is cited as a synonym of B. trigyna (Iljin 1952). There are hexaploid and tetraploid individuals of B. trigyna and it is possible that B. hybrida is a tetraploid form of B. trigyna (V. Melnyk pers. comm 2010). The view that B. hybrida is a synonym of B. trigyna is now supported by Uotila (2011); however, The Plant List (2010) (based on data derived from the World Checklist of Selected Plant Families in review) records the taxon as a synonym of B. vulgaris L.

The taxonomic status of this species therefore requires clarification.

Brassica cadmea O.E. Schulz is a wild relative of a number of crops in the brassica group; including broccoli, B. oleracea L. var. italica Plenck, Brussels sprout, B. oleracea L. var. gemmifera (DC.) Zenker, cabbage, B. oleracea var. capitata L., cauliflower, B. oleracea var. botrytis L., kale, B. oleracea var. viridis L., swede, B. napus L. var. napobrassica (L.) Rchb., turnip, B. rapa L. ssp. rapa, and oilseed rape, B. napus L. var. napus.

Brassica incana Ten. is a secondary wild relative of kale, B. oleracea var. viridis L. (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2010) and a tertiary wild relative of a number of other crops in the brassica group; including broccoli, B. oleracea L. var. italica Plenck, Brussels sprout, B. oleracea L. var. gemmifera (DC.) Zenker, cabbage, B. oleracea var. capitata L., cauliflower, B. oleracea var. botrytis L., swede, B. napus L. var. napobrassica (L.) Rchb., turnip, B. rapa L. ssp. rapa, and oilseed rape, B. napus L. var. napus.

Brassica oleracea L. is a wild relative of a number of crops in the brassica group; including broccoli, B. oleracea L. var. italica Plenck, Brussels sprout, B. oleracea L. var. gemmifera (DC.) Zenker, cabbage, B. oleracea var. capitata L., cauliflower, B. oleracea var. botrytis L., kale, B. oleracea var. viridis L., swede, B. napus L. var. napobrassica (L.) Rchb., turnip, B. rapa L. ssp. rapa, and oilseed rape, B. napus L. var. napus.

Two subspecies are native to Europe: B. oleracea ssp. bourgeaui (Webb) Gladis & K. Hammer and B. oleracea L. ssp. oleracea (Euro+Med PlantBase 2006). B. oleracea ssp. bourgeaui is recognized at specific level as B. bourgeaui (Webb) O. Kuntze in some taxonomic treatments.

Prunus klokovii (Sobko) is a wild relative of almond, P. dulcis (Mill.) D. A. Webb, peach and nectarine, P. persica (L.) Batsch, plum, P. domestica L., sloe, P. spinosa L. and sweet cherry, P. avium (L.) L. It is very closely related to P. fruticosa.

Allium aethusanum Garbari is a tertiary wild relative of a number of crops in the allium group, including onion (A. cepa L.), Welsh onion (A. fistulosum L.), leek (A. porrum L.), garlic (A. sativum L.) and chives (A. schoenoprasum L.).

Allium narcissiflorum Vill. is a tertiary wild relative of a number of crops in the allium group, including onion (A. cepa L.), Welsh onion (A. fistulosum L.), leek (A. porrum L.), garlic (A. sativum L.) and chives (A. schoenoprasum L.).

Allium hymettium Boiss. & Heldr. is a tertiary wild relative of a number of crops in the allium group, including onion (A. cepa L.), Welsh onion (A. fistulosum L.), leek (A. porrum L.), garlic (A. sativum L.) and chives (A. schoenoprasum L.).
The species is considered a synonym of Allium phthioticum Boiss. & Heldr. by Andersson (1991) and WCSP (2017).

Allium pilosum Sibth. & Sm. is a tertiary wild relative of a number of crops in the allium group, including onion (A. cepa L.), Welsh onion (A. fistulosum L.), leek (A. porrum L.), garlic (A. sativum L.) and chives (A. schoenoprasum L.).

Allium bornmuelleri Hayek is a tertiary wild relative of a number of crops in the Allium group, including onion (A. cepa L.), Welsh Onion (A. fistulosum L.), leek (A. porrum L.), garlic (A. sativum L.) and chives (A. schoenoprasum L.).

Allium podolicum Racib. & Szafer is a tertiary wild relative of a number of crops in the allium group, including onion (A. cepa L.), Welsh onion (A. fistulosum L.), leek (A. porrum L.), garlic (A. sativum L.) and chives (A. schoenoprasum L.).

Allium favosum Zahar. is a tertiary wild relative of a number of crops in the allium group, including onion (A. cepa L.), Welsh onion (A. fistulosum L.), leek (A. porrum L.), garlic (A. sativum L.) and chives (A. schoenoprasum L.).
Lactuca longidentata Moris ex DC. is a tertiary wild relative of lettuce, L. sativa L. (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2010).
Malus crescimannoi Raimondo is a wild relative of apple, Malus domestica Borkh. It is a preliminary accepted species in Euro+Med PlantBase (Kurtto 2009).

Allium circinnatum Sieber is a tertiary wild relative of a number of crops in the allium group, including onion (A. cepa L.), Welsh onion (A. fistulosum L.), leek (A. porrum L.), garlic (A. sativum L.) and chives (A. schoenoprasum L.). According to Turland et al. (1993), there are two subspecies: A. circinnatum ssp. circinnatum Sieber (endemic to Crete) and A. circinnatum ssp. peloponnesiacum Tzanoud. which occurs in southern Greece—with a suspected population near the coast of southwestern Turkey (Fielding and Turland 2005). However, as Euro+Med PlantBase (2006) does not recognize ssp. peloponnesiacum, this assessment  is only for the Cretan population, ssp. circinnatum.

Allium macedonicum Zahar. is a tertiary wild relative of a number of crops in the allium group, including onion (A. cepa L.), Welsh onion (A. fistulosum L.), leek (A. porrum L.), garlic (A. sativum L.) and chives (A. schoenoprasum L.).

Allium obtusiflorum DC. is a tertiary wild relative of and potential gene donor to a number of crops in the allium group, including onion (A. cepa L.), Welsh onion (A. fistulosum L.), leek (A. porrum L.), garlic (A. sativum L.) and chives (A. schoenoprasum L.).

Allium scythicum Zoz is a tertiary wild relative of a number of crops in the allium group, including onion (A. cepa L.), Welsh onion (A. fistulosum L.), leek (A. porrum L.), garlic (A. sativum L.) and chives (A. schoenoprasum L.). According to Mathew (1996) the species may be conspecific with A. regelianum—it was described from east of Herson (Ukraine), but field studies are required to assess the status of this taxon, and the relationships between it, A. regelianum and A. sphaeracephalon. However, according to V. Melnyk (pers. comm. 2010) it is a valid species.

Allium talijevii is only described from a single specimen collected in 1898 and has not been collected since. It is thought that the type specimen is actually a form of A. ampeloprasum (V. Melnyk pers. comm. 2010).

Allium heldreichii Boiss. is a tertiary wild relative of a number of crops in the allium group, including onion (A. cepa L.), Welsh onion (A. fistulosum L.), leek (A. porrum L.), garlic (A. sativum L.) and chives (A. schoenoprasum L.).

Allium ericetorum Thore is a tertiary wild relative of a number of crops in the allium group, including onion (A. cepa L.), Welsh onion (A. fistulosum L.), leek (A. porrum L.), garlic (A. sativum L.) and chives (A. schoenoprasum L.).

Allium pruinatum Spreng. is a tertiary wild relative of a number of crops in the allium group, including onion (A. cepa L.), Welsh onion (A. fistulosum L.), leek (A. porrum L.), garlic (A. sativum L.) and chives (A. schoenoprasum L.). A bulbiferous variant has been described as A. pruinatum var. bulbiferum Cout. (endemic to Portugal).

Although A. pruinatum is thought to be endemic to Portugal, A. rubrovittatum var. occidentale Rouy ex Willkomm (based on a specimen collected at Algerciras in southern Spain) is regarded by Stearn (1978) and by Pastor Díaz and Valdés (1983) as a synonym of A. pruinatum (Mathew 1996).
Lactuca plumieri (L.) Gren. & Godr. is a wild relative of lettuce, L. sativa L.

Three subspecies are native to Europe: M. sylvestris subsp. orientalis (Uglitzk.) Browicz, M. sylvestris subsp. praecox (Pall.) Soó and M. sylvestris (L.) Mill. subsp. sylvestris (Kurtto 2009).

Malus sylvestris (L.) Mill. is a primary wild relative of apple, M. domestica Borkh. (GRIN 2010).

Allium parnassicum (Boiss.) Halácsy is a tertiary wild relative of a number of crops in the allium group, including onion (A. cepa L.), Welsh onion (A. fistulosum L.), leek (A. porrum L.), garlic (A. sativum L.) and chives (A. schoenoprasum L.).
Daucus halophilus Brot. is considered in some taxonomic treatments as a subspecies of D. carota (D. carota ssp. halophilus (Brot) A. Pujadas). The taxon is closely related to carrot, D. carota L.

The nomenclatural status of the species should be reconsidered (see Brullo et al. 2010) who commented that the characters of this species are well within the bounds of A. permixtum, and proposed to include both A. phthioticum and A. breviradium as synonyms of A. permixtum). For this assessment, the Annotated Checklist of Greek Flora (Dimopoulous et al. 2013) is followed.

WCSP (2018) considers Allium breviradium (Halácsy) Stearn (and Allium neapolitanum var. breviradiatum Halácsy to be synonyms of this species.

Allium kermesinum Rchb. is a tertiary wild relative of a number of crops in the allium group, including onion (A. cepa L.), Welsh onion (A. fistulosum L.), leek (A. porrum L.), garlic (A. sativum L.) and chives (A. schoenoprasum L.).

Allium insubricum Boiss. & Reut. is a tertiary wild relative of a number of crops in the allium group, including onion (A. cepa L.), Welsh onion (A. fistulosum L.), leek (A. porrum L.), garlic (A. sativum L.) and chives (A. schoenoprasum L.).

Allium integerrimum is a doubtful taxon and may belong to Allium sphaerocephalon subsp. sphaerocephalon (P. Delipetrou and I. Bazos pers. comm. 2015).

Allium integerrimum Zahar. is a tertiary wild relative of a number of crops in the Allium group, including onion (A. cepa L.), Welsh onion (A. fistulosum L.), leek (A. porrum L.), garlic (A. sativum L.) and chives (A. schoenoprasum L.).

Allium meteoricum belongs to Allium s. Scorodon. It is related to Allium lagarophyllum, and records of Allium meteoricum from southern mainland Greece (Sterea Ellias) refer instead to Allium lagarophyllum (D. Tzanoudakis pers. comm. 2018).

Brullo et al. (2001) compared herbarium material and considered that plants from the type locality are morphologically well differentiated from the specimens collected in other Balkan localities and attributed to this species, and considered A. meteoricum to be restricted to the Meteora hills in central Greece. Records of the species from places other than Meteora (the type locality) require confirmation.

The considered 'unplaced' by WCSP (2015) and not found in Euro+Med (2014).

Allium incensiodorum Radić is a tertiary wild relative of a number of crops in the allium group, including onion (A. cepa L.), Welsh onion (A. fistulosum L.), leek (A. porrum L.), garlic (A. sativum L.) and chives (A. schoenoprasum L.).

Allium lopadusanum Bartolo, Brullo & Pavone is a tertiary wild relative of a number of crops in the allium group, including onion (A. cepa L.), Welsh onion (A. fistulosum L.), leek (A. porrum L.), garlic (A. sativum L.) and chives (A. schoenoprasum L.). It shows some relationships with A. lojaconoi from the Maltese Islands and belongs to Allium sect. Brevispatha (Bartolo et al. 1986).

Allium chrysonemum Stearn is included as an accepted taxon in Euro+Med PlantBase (2006) and is recognized by Govaerts et al. (2005–2007). However, according to Spanish experts present at a European CWR Red List workshop held in April 2010, the species is a synonym of A. rouyi. The taxonomic status of this species therefore requires clarification. The species is a tertiary wild relative of a number of crops in the allium group, including onion (A. cepa L.), Welsh onion (A. fistulosum L.), leek (A. porrum L.), garlic (A. sativum L.) and chives (A. schoenoprasum L.).
Lactuca perennis L. is a wild relative of lettuce, L. sativa L.

Allium luteolum Halácsy is a tertiary wild relative of a number of crops in the allium group, including onion (A. cepa L.), Welsh onion (A. fistulosum L.), leek (A. porrum L.), garlic (A. sativum L.) and chives (A. schoenoprasum L.).

Allium lehmannii (Lojac.) Gillett is a tertiary wild relative of a number of crops in the allium group, including onion (A. cepa L.), Welsh onion (A. fistulosum L.), leek (A. porrum L.), garlic (A. sativum L.) and chives (A. schoenoprasum L.).

Allium marschalianum Vved. is a tertiary wild relative of a number of crops in the allium group, including onion (A. cepa L.), Welsh onion (A. fistulosum L.), leek (A. porrum L.), garlic (A. sativum L.) and chives (A. schoenoprasum L.).

Allium horvatii was described as a local endemic of exposed saline maritime rocks (elev. 3-350 m asl) of Krk Island, Croatia. Seregin et al. (2015) failed to find any consistent characters to separate A. horvatii from A. saxatile ssp. tergestinum, which is known to occur all around the Adriatic coast and no genetic variation was detected within the Adriatic entity from central Italy to Montenegro. They therefore recognized the westernmost entity of the A. saxatile group as a single species, with A. horvatii is its oldest valid name.

Allium chamaespathum Boiss. is a tertiary wild relative of a number of crops in the allium group, including onion (A. cepa L.), Welsh onion (A. fistulosum L.), leek (A. porrum L.), garlic (A. sativum L.) and chives (A. schoenoprasum L.).
Avena volgensis (Vavilov) Nevski is a wild relative of oats, Avena sativa L. and A. byzantina K. Koch.

Allium palentinum Losa & P. Monts. is a tertiary wild relative of a number of crops in the allium group, including onion (A. cepa L.), Welsh onion (A. fistulosum L.), leek (A. porrum L.), garlic (A. sativum L.) and chives (A. schoenoprasum L.).
Pyrus vallis-demonis is a wild relative of pear, P. communis L. subsp. communis. It is a preliminary accepted species in Euro+Med PlantBase (Kurtto 2009).

Halophila euphlebia has recently been recognized as distinct by Uchimura et al. (2006, 2008); however, previous evidence suggested that it is possibly a synonym of H. ovalis (McMahon 2005) or H. major (Kua et al. 2006).
Halophila sulawesii is a very newly described species (Kuo 2007), with no genetic information.

The taxonomy of this species is questionable and it is listed as a synonym of H. wrightii (Hammel et al. 2003). Its taxonomic status is based on leaf-tip morphology which is highly variable (Larkum et al. 2006).
Halodule ciliata was originally described as Diplanthera ciliata.

The taxonomy of this species is questionable and it may eventually be found as conspecific with Halodule wrightii. Its taxonomic status is based on leaf-tip morphology which is highly variable (Larkum et al. 2006).

The taxonomy of the Ruppia genus is uncertain due to difficulties of identification. Species can be extremely morphologically variable and respond to differing environmental conditions. Problems in species identification are linked to differences in environmental conditions.

Originally described as Halodule wrightii,  and re-described as H. bermudensis in 1970. Current status is unclear. Recent collections in Bermuda reveal specimens of Halodule sp. that do not match the type specimen for Halodule bermudensis, and have been identified as H. wrightii. The status of Halodule bermudensis is therefore unknown, and  it is in need of genetic review to determine if it is a distinct species and requires more research to find this morphotype in Bermuda.

Medicago tenderiensis Opperman ex Klokov is a primary wild relative of the widely cultivated M. sativa L. ssp. sativa, commonly known as alfalfa (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2010). Atawneh et al. (2009) consider Medicago tenderiensis is a synonym of Medicago sativa ssp. falcata (L.) Arcang.
There are no significant taxonomic issues associated with this name.
Isoetes subinermis is recognised by very few authors.

Prelli (2001) presents detailed and informative argument for the inclusion of Isoetes brochonii within I. lacustris, although Prada and Rolleri (2005) claim to have demonstrated that it is a good species.
The main taxonomic issue is whether Motelay’s type is dodecaploid – that is can the cytologically distinct allopolyploid Pyrenean plant recorded by Taylor and Hickey (1992) and subsequently morphologically studied by Prada and Rolleri (2003) be identified with Motelay’s plant.

Flora Iberica and the International Plant Names Index do not mention this name (not even as a synonym). It is therefore not considered as a valid species and is not evaluated.
There are no significant taxonomic issues associated with this name.

Euro+Med PlantBase (2006), which currently forms the taxonomic core of the CWR Catalogue for Europe and the Mediterranean (Kell et al. 2005) noted that Lepidium syvaschicum Kleopow is a doubtful species, close to L. cartilagineum (J.C. Mayer) Thell. and therefore listed it as a preliminary accepted species. In a recent review and update of Euro+Med PlantBase, Marhold (2011) lists the taxon as a synonym of L. cartilagineum. In this assessment, data are provided for subpopulations of the taxon which is recognized as L. syvaschicum in Ukraine.

The taxon is a wild relative of brassica crops and garden cress, L. sativum L.

Isatis littoralis DC. is a wild relative of brassica crops and of dyer's woad, I. tinctoria L. Euro+Med PlantBase (2006) notes that this is a doubtful species, close to I. tinctoria; it is therefore a preliminary accepted species.
Barbarea bracteosa Guss. is a wild relative of the cultivated Barbarea species, B. verna (Mill.) Asch. (land cress), and B. vulgaris R. Br. (winter cress).

Rorippa hispanica (Boiss. & Reut.) Willk. is included as an accepted taxon in Euro+Med PlantBase (2006) which forms the taxonomic core of the CWR Catalogue for Europe and the Mediterranean (Kell et al. 2005) for the Brassicaceae family. However, Euro+Med PlantBase has recently been updated for the Brassicaceae family and the taxon is now considered to be a synonym of R. pyrenaica (All.) Rchb. (Marhold 2011) (although the CWR Catalogue for Europe and the Mediterranean has not yet been updated in line with this change). The Plant List (2010) (based on data derived from the World Checklist of Selected Plant Families in review) also records the taxon as a synonym of R. pyrenaica, a view shared by Spanish experts present at a European CWR Red List workshop held in April 2010.

Tutin et al. (1964) included it as an accepted species but within the R. pyrenaica (Lam.) Reichenb. taxon concept, noting that it has "subcylindrical fruits equalling the pedicels".

The taxon is a wild relative of watercress, Nasturtium officinale W.T. Aiton and N. microphyllum Boenn. ex Rchb.

Crambe grandiflora DC. is a wild relative of the oil producing and fodder crop, C. abyssinica R.E. Fr., as well as being related to other brassica crops as a member of the subtribe Brassicinae (tribe Brassiceae) (Maxted et al. in prep.).

Lepidium ramburei Boiss. is included as an accepted taxon in Euro+Med PlantBase (2006) which forms the taxonomic core of the CWR Catalogue for Europe and the Mediterranean (Kell et al. 2005) for the Brassicaceae family.  However, Euro+Med PlantBase has recently been updated for the Brassicaceae family and the taxon is now considered to be a synonym of L. villarsii ssp. anticarium (Valdés Berm. & G. López) Hern.-Berm. (Marhold 2011) (although the CWR Catalogue for Europe and the Mediterranean has not yet been updated in line with this change). The Plant List (2010) (based on data derived from the World Checklist of Selected Plant Families in review) also records the taxon as a synonym of Lepidium villarsii ssp. anticarium and according to Spanish experts present at a European CWR Red List workshop held in April 2010, the taxon is a synonym of L. villarsii.

Tutin et al. (1964) included it as an accepted species but within the L. villarsii Gren & Godron taxon concept, noting that "plants up to 22 cm, with leaves glabrous or almost so, pedicels 5–6 mm in fruit and silicula about 7x6 mm, from S.E. Spain, are probably L. ramburei Boiss, Voy. Bot. Midi Esp. 2: 52 (1839) and may represent a third subspecies".

The taxon is a wild relative of brassica crops and garden cress, L. sativum L.
Barbarea verna (Mill.) Asch. is a primary wild relative of cultivated B. verna (Mill.) Asch. (land cress) and a wild relative of winter cress, B. vulgaris R. Br.

Strid (1986) wrote that the status of Barbarea conferta Boiss. & Heldr. is uncertain. It was described from Mt. Killini and "differs from B. vulgaris in the raceme scarcely elongating in fruit, and pedicels 2–4 mm" (Strid 1986).

If a valid taxon, it is a wild relative of the cultivated Barbarea species, B. verna (Mill.) Asch. (land cress), and B. vulgaris R. Br. (winter cress).

Isatis vermia Papan. is a wild relative of brassica crops and of dyer's woad, I. tinctoria L. Strid (1986) notes that I. vermia is related to the widespread and variable species, I. tinctoria, but differs in the flowering period and a combination of morphological characters. This is reflected by Euro+Med PlantBase (2006), who note that this is a doubtful species, close to I. tinctoria, and is therefore a preliminary accepted species.
Barbarea longirostris Velen. is a wild relative of the cultivated Barbarea species, B. verna (Mill.) Asch. (land cress), and B. vulgaris R. Br. (winter cress).

Asparagus littoralis Steven is a wild relative of asparagus, A. officinalis L. Yena (1999) excluded Asparagus littoralis from the list of endemic species of Crimea and regarded its populations on the Crimean peninsula as A. officinalis L.
Isatis tomentella Boiss. & Balansa is a wild relative of brassica crops and of dyer's woad, I. tinctoria L.

Barbarea bosniaca Murb. is a wild relative of the cultivated Barbarea species, B. verna (Mill.) Asch. (land cress), and B. vulgaris R. Br. (winter cress). It is closely related to Barbarea sicula C. Presl. and B. intermedia Boreau.

There is some uncertainty about the validity of Barbarea macrophylla (Halácsy) Halácsy. It was described in 1899 from Pilion in eastern Greece but according to Tutin et al. (1964) and Strid (1986) is probably only a variant of B. vulgaris.

If a valid taxon, it is a wild relative of the cultivated Barbarea species, B. verna (Mill.) Asch. (land cress), and B. vulgaris R. Br. (winter cress).

Lepidium carrerasii J.J. Rodr. is a preliminary accepted species in Euro+Med PlantBase (2006) which forms the taxonomic core of the CWR Catalogue for Europe and the Mediterranean (Kell et al. 2005) for the Brassicaceae family. However, Euro+Med PlantBase has recently been updated for the Brassicaceae family and the taxon is now considered to be a synonym of L. spinosum Ard. (Marhold 2011) (although the CWR Catalogue for Europe and the Mediterranean has not yet been updated in line with this change). Tutin et al. (1964) and The Plant List (2010) (based on data from the World Checklist of Selected Plant Families in review) also record the taxon as a synonym of L. spinosum.

The taxon is a wild relative of brassica crops and of garden cress, L. sativum L.
Asparagus pseudoscaber Grecescu is a wild relative of asparagus, A. officinalis L.

According to Euro+Med PlantBase (2006) which currently forms the taxonomic core of the CWR Catalogue for Europe and the Mediterranean (Kell et al. 2005) for the Brassicaceae family, I. villarsii is an accepted species. However, in a recent revision of Euro+Med PlantBase, Marhold (2011) lists the taxon as a synonym of I. tinctoria. In this assessment, data are provided for subpopulations of the taxon which is recognized as I. villarsii in Ukraine.

The taxon is a wild relative of brassica crops and of dyer's woad, I. tinctoria L.
Isatis arenaria Azn. is a wild relative of brassica crops and of dyer's woad, I. tinctoria L.
Barbarea sicula C. Presl is a wild relative of the cultivated Barbarea species, B. verna (Mill.) Asch. (land cress), and B. vulgaris R. Br. (winter cress).
Isatis allionii P.W. Ball is a wild relative of brassica crops and of dyer's woad, I. tinctoria L. Conti et al. (2005) recognize this species as Isatis apennina Grande.

Medicago heterocarpa Spach is a tertiary wild relative of the cultivated crop alfalfa, M. sativa ssp. sativa. Association Tela Botanica (2000) and Al-Atawneh et al. (2009) consider this as a synonym of M. murex which has a wider distribution and which is also an accepted species in Euro+Med PlantBase (2006) and in our list for assessment.

Isoetes udupiensis was reported by Shukla et al. (2005) from Alevoor, Udupi, Karnataka. The type is PK Shukla 8399 . Holotype is deposited in CAL and isotypes are in K, DD. But Fraser-Jenkins (2008) considers this as a dubious taxon, doubtfully endemic.
Eleocharis swamyi is a doubtful species. Cook (1996) comments that all species of the Eleocharis variegata group need of taxonomic revision.
Limnophila glandulifera is known only from a single collection from Travancore (Cook 1996).
Aponogeton appendiculatus is identified based on terminal plumule, germinating embryo warty, and crowned with a whorl of bent linear or conical about 1 cm long appendages.
Algaebase cite this species as of uncertain taxonomic status.
Eleocharis wadoodii is similar to E. tetraquetra (Yadav et al. 2009).

Bolbitis aspleniifolia was earlier considered a variety of B. appendiculata. Majid et al. (1994, 1995) consider this taxon as a synonym of B. appendiculata. However, the taxon is morphologically and ecologically distinct from B. appendiculata (V. Irudayaraj pers. comm. 2011).
Chara setosa is an synonym of Chara brachypus (Srinivasan 1965). However it is accepted in AlgaeBase as a valid name (Guiry and Guiry 2011).

Scleria poklei is named after the author's close friend Dr. Dileep Pokle, Reader in Botany, Deogiri College, Aurangabad, for his contributions in the field of taxonomy and in Flora of Marathwada (1998) by V.N. Naik. This species is very similar to Scleria reticulata (Holtt.) Kern but differs in having 3-lobbed and distinctly several nerved glumes of female spikelets and etuberculate nuts with sparsely hispidulous apex.

Taxonomic status of this recently described species to be reviewed.

Isoetes divyadarshanii was reported by Shukla et al. (2005) from Lonavala, Pune, Maharashtra. The type is PK Shukla 8400. The type specimens of S. pulchella collected from Lebanon by Charles Isidore Blanche were used by Boissier to describe the taxon in Flora Orientalis (Boissier 1867-1884, Haber and Semaan 2010). The review of the genus by Mathew (1983) excludes it from the Flora of Turkey (1984) indicating that the attribution of S. pulchella to Alexandretta and the surrounding mountains is not verified and that it may be synonymous with S. sicula. Possibly the collection that Mouterde (1966) mentions ‘between Aleppo and Alexandretta’ is nearer to Aleppo. Until today, the species has not been observed on the eastern slopes of the Mount Lebanon mountain range nor from Lebanon’s inland areas. Judging from the occurrence and habitat of the species in Lebanon, the heights of the Ansariyah Mountains in Syria are more of an equivalent habitat than Aleppo; however there is no reference of the presence of the species on these mountains. This raises the question on the taxonomic validity and the occurrence of the species in Aleppo and up to Mosul. These collections could be the outskirt extension of a species from the Irano-Mesopotamian zone, taking foothold westward along more humid zones of mountains, valleys and lakes (M. Semaan pers. comm. 2017).

The affinity of S. pulchella to S. sicula needs to be verified as Mathew (1983) cautions. Yet, the geographical discontinuity in the distribution of these species would suggest allopatric speciation by genetic deviation based on geographical isolation (M. Semaan pers. comm. 2017).
