Prunus webbii is a wild relative of Plum P. domestica, Sloe P. spinosa and Sweet Cherry P. avium.

It also belongs to the primary Gene Pool of Almond P. dulcis and the secondary Gene Pool of Peach P. persica (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).

Prunus cerasifera Ehrh. is a wild relative of Almond, P. dulcis (Mill.) D.A.Webb, Peach and Nectarine, P. persica (L.) Batsch, Plum, P. domestica L., Sloe, P. spinosa L. and Sweet Cherry, P. avium (L.) L.

For this assessment only the remaining wild population of the species is considered.

Medicago soleirolii Duby belongs to the section Spirocarpos, subsection Pachyspireae. It is a secondary wild relative of the cultivated crop M. truncatula Gaertn., commonly known as Barrel Clover, and is a tertiary wild relative of cultivated Alfalfa, M. sativa L. subsp. sativa (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2010).

The taxonomy of this species is debated. Breteler (1960) reduces Abrus pulchellus and A.mollis and others to synonyms of A.fruticulosus. Kumar and Sane (2003), for example, list A. fruticulosus as a recognized species with no synonyms.
This species is only known from the description (Bojer 1837), there is no further data about the species and there is some uncertainty about the taxonomy and the validity of the name at present.
Astragalus abnormalis is included in the section Incani (Mehrabian et al. 2007)
Astragalus buschiorum Galuschko is closely related to A. demetri Charadze and differs on the stem, densely covered with the remains of dead leaves, larger leaves and violet red rim (Galushko 1970).

There is some confusion in regard to the names Astragalus cytisoides or A. cytisodes. Bunge originally published section Cytisodes with only one species A. cytisoides in 1968 but did not give a description for the species. It was Regel in 1874 who then gave A. cytisoides a description.
Astragalus ikonnikovii is the species of Subsect. Erionotus that grows at the highest altitude (Podlech 1988).
This species seems to be close to Astragalus zanskarensis Benth. ex. Bunge (Chaudhary pers. comm. 2011).

Although the species name was published as Astragalus retufoliatus Y.C.Ho, an orthographic correction of the name was made by Podlech in Thesaurus Astragalorum in 2008, and the proposed name is Astragalus retusifoliatus Y.C.Ho.

There has been a recent transfer of the genus, the species was originally described as Astragalus zemuensis W.W.Sm and in 2006 the new combination Oxtropis zemuensis (W.W.Sm.) L.B.Chaudhary was published (Chaudhary 2006).

The genus Caragana has over 80 species out of which 10 species have so far been identified in Pakistan. Caragana species are deciduous shrubs distributed widely throughout the Euro-Asian continent, from Northern Europe and central Asia, eastwards to Russian Siberia, Korea and Japan, and south to Nepal, Bhutan, Sikkim and northern India (Meng et al. 2009).
Previously Cassia caracensis H.S.Irwin & Barneby.

Crotalaria johannis occurs just north of the range of C. variegata in Angola and it is not excluded that it might be an extreme variant of C. variegata (Polhill 1982). For the purposes of this assessment it is treated as a separate species.
There is some uncertainty on the nomenclatural status of this species (African Plant Database version 3.3).
Verdcourt (1970) described Kotschya oubanguiensi as being very close to K. stolonifera.

There are taxonomic doubts about the validity of this species name. It has first been published by Harms (1925), but Baker (1929) stated that it might represent a possible form of Leptoderris. glabrata, but without recognizing it as a synonym of the species. The species has been then listed in the provisional names in the Legumes of Africa: a checklist (Lock 1989), meaning that there are still doubts about the species name. The species is here treated as a valid name until further study clarifies its taxonomic status.
Possibly of hybrid origin (Akiyama 1988).
This was considered as a new species in 1968 (Ali 1968) to describe the plant treated under Millettia ovalifolia Kurz.
This species is close to Ormosia robusta and further taxonomic work is recommended to clarify the species delimitation.
Rhynchosia crispa has been described as closely related to R. pulchra (Verdcourt 1971).

The taxonomy for this species is not precisely defined. The species is currently only known from a specimen (Drege #s.n.) collected in what is today KwaZulu-Natal province (South Africa). No further specimens or observations of this species are currently available, and this is mainly due to its taxonomic uncertainty (Baker 1923, African Plant Database version 3.3). Baker (1923) in his revision of the South African Rhyncosia species, inscribed R. nitida between the imperfectly known species, explaining that following the specimen (Drege #s.n.) description, in which the plant was described as having three seeds, it has to be excluded that it was a Rhyncosia species, as the ovary in that genus only has two ovules.
Two recognized varieties: var. barbatala from Papua New Guinea and Queensland and var. glabra Bosman & De Haas from Papua New Guinea.
Further work is required to define species limits and at least one of the Northern Territory records is a misidentification (I. Cowie pers. comm. 2010).

There is some uncertainty about the taxonomic placement of this species, as it might be synonym of Tephrosia angustissima as suggested by Wunderlin and Hansen (2008), but is here treated as an accepted name until its taxonomic status is clarified.
This species may be a form of Tephrosia remotiflora Benth. (I. Cowie pers. comm. 2010).

Z. quilonensis was descibed as a new species of Zornia in 1969 (Ravi 1970), however, Pramanik (1990) notes that this species was originally described from peninsular India as Zornia angustifolia var. oblongifolia W & A. Pramanik (1990) considers that a specimen misidentified as Zornia diphylla (L.) Pers from West Bengal is Z. quilonensis and also that usually the identity of Z. quilonensis is confused with the Ceylonese species Z. walkeri Arnot. A specimen in the Edinburgh herbarium collected from India by R. Wight was determined as Z. gibbosa by Grierson, A.J.C and Long, D.G in 1978, but is now labelled as a syntype of Z angustifolia var. oblongifolia.

Allium oschaninii O.Fedtsch. is a tertiary wild relative of A. cepa L.; it also belongs to Taxon Group 3 of Chinese Scallion A. chinense G.Don and Chives A. schoenoprasum L. (Friesen et al. 2006, USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013, Vincent et al. 2013).
Allium scabriscapum Boiss. belongs to the secondary Gene Pool of Chinese Chive A. tuberosum Rottler ex Spreng. (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013, Vincent et al. 2013).
Ilex argentina Lillo belongs to the secondary Gene Pool of yerba maté Ilex paraguariensis A. St.-Hil. (Cuénoud et al. 2000, Manen et al. 2002, Vincent et al. 2013).
Asparagus oligoclonos Maxim. belongs to the secondary Gene Pool of cultivated Asparagus (A. officinalis L.) (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).
Asparagus cochinchinensis is a tertiary genetic relative of Asparagus A. officinalis L. (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).
Allium oliganthum Kar. & Kir. belongs to Taxon Group 2 of Chives A. schoenoprasum L. and Taxon Group 3 of Chinese Scallion A. chinense G.Don (Friesen et al. 2006, Vincent et al. 2013).
Asparagus dauricus Fisch. ex Link is a secondary genetic relative of cultivated Asparagus (A. officinalis L.).
Allium weschniakowii Regel belongs to Taxon Group 3 of both Chinese Scallion A. chinense G.Don and Chives A. schoenoprasum L. (Friesen et al. 2006, Vincent et al. 2013).

Based on the interpretation of the Bread Wheat gene pool of van Slageren (1994), Aegilops juvenalis (Thell.) Eig is a secondary wild relative of Bread Wheat, Triticum aestivum L. ssp. aestivum, Durum Wheat, T. turgidum ssp. durum (Desf.) Husn., and a number of other cultivated wheats—including Emmer Wheat, T. turgidum ssp. dicoccon (Schrank) Thell., Einkorn Wheat, T. monococcum L. ssp. monococcum, Spelt, T. aestivum ssp. spelta (L.) Thell., and Sanduri Wheat, T. timopheevii (Zhuk.) Zhuk. ssp. timopheevii.

Allium galanthum Kar. & Kir. is a secondary wild relative of Onion A. cepa L., Welsh Onion A. fistulosum L; it also belongs to Taxon Group 3 of Chinese Scallion A. chinense G. Don and Chives A. schoenprasum L. (Friesen et al. 2006, USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013, Vincent et al. 2013).
Allium thunbergii G.Don belongs to Taxon Group 2 of Chinese Scallion A. chinense G.Don and Taxon Group 3 of Chives A. schoenoprasum L. (Friesen et al. 2006, Vincent et al. 2013).
Asparagus filicinus Buch.-Ham. ex D.Don is a tertiary genetic relative of cultivated Asparagus A. officinalis (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).
Wild Carica papaya L. is a primary genetic relative of the cultivated Papaya (C. papaya) (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2016).

In the literature, spelling of this species varies between Pistacia weinmannifolia and P. weinmanniifolia, the latter of which is in accordance with the Melbourne edition of the International Code of Nomenclature (ICN) Art. 60.8 and Rec. 60G (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).

This species is a secondary genetic relative of cultivated Pistachio P. vera L.

Allium pskemense B.Fedtsch. is a tertiary wild relative of A. cepa L. and Welsh Onion A. fistulosum L.; it also belongs to Taxon Group 3 of Chinese Scallion A. chinense G.Don and Chives A. schoenoprasum L. (Friesen et al. 2006, USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013, Vincent et al. 2013).

Belonging to the subgenus Cepa and section Cepa (Brewster 2008), Allium asarense R.M.Fritsch & Matin is a tertiary wild relative of Onion A. cepa L. and also belongs to Taxon Group 3 of Chinese Scallion A. chinense G. Don and Chives A. schoenoprasum L. (Friesen et al. 2006, USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program, Vincent et al. 2013)

Allium karelinii Polijakov is a tertiary wild relative of Onion A. cepa L; it also belongs to Taxon Group 2 of Chives A. schoenoprasum L. and Taxon Group 3 of A. chinense G.Don (Friesen et al. 2006, USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013, Vincent et al. 2013).

Allium praemixtum Vved. is a tertiary wild relative of A. cepa L.; it also belongs to Taxon Group 3 of Chinese Scallion A. chinense G.Don and Chives A. schoenoprasum L. (Friesen et al. 2006, USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013, Vincent et al. 2013).
Helianthus arizonensis R.C.Jacks. belongs to the tertiary Gene Pool of Sunflower H. annuus L. and Taxon Group four of Jerusalem Artichoke H. tuberosus L.
The species Helianthus deserticola belongs to the secondary Gene Pool of Sunflower H. annuus L. and Taxon Group four of the Jerusalem Artichoke H. tuberosus L.
Helianthus neglectus Heiser belongs to the secondary Gene Pool of Sunflower H. annuus L. and Taxon Group four of Jerusalem Artichoke H. tuberosus L.

Helianthus niveus (Benth.) Brandegee belongs to the secondary Gene Pool of cultivated Sunflower H. annuus L. and Taxon Group four of the Jerusalem Artichoke H. tuberosus L. (Schilling and Heiser 1981, USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).

Cucurbita okeechobeensis is a secondary genetic relative of Moschata Pumpkin/Squash (C. moschata) and Pepo Pumpkin/Squash (C. pepo), and a tertiary genetic relative of Cushaw (C. argyrosperma), Fig-leaf Gourd (C. ficifolia) and Maxima Pumpkin/Squash (C. maxima) (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2016).
Arena strigosa Schreb. belongs to the tertiary Gene Pool of A. sativa L.
Hordeum cordobense Bothmer, N.Jacobsen & Nicora is a tertiary genetic relative of Barley (H. vulgare L.) (von Bothmer et al. 1995).
Eleusine kigeziensis S.M.Phillips is a primary wild relative of Finger Millet E. coracana (L.) Gaertn. (Phillips 1972).
Hordeum procerum Nevski is a tertiary genetic relative of Barley (H. vulgare L.) (von Bothmer et al. 1995).
Eleusine intermedia (Chiov.) S.M.Phillips belongs to the secondary Gene Pool of Finger Millet E. coracana (L.) Gaertn. (Phillips 1972).
The previous concept of Nepenthes pilosa included N. chaniana; Clarke et al. (2006) split chaniana from pilosa as a good species.

This species was validly published in 1913 (Lecomte 1913) and should not be confused with an illegitimate later homonyn Eriocaulon longipendunculatum Silveria which was published in 1928 from Brazil. There are five species of Eriocaulon that occur in New Caledonia (J.-M.Veillon pers. comm. 2016). There is no revision of the genus and identification of herbarium specimens is difficult (V.Huquet pers. comm. 2016).

This is considered to be the accepted name of this orchid in the World Checklist of Selected Plant Families (WCSP 2013) which is followed in this assessment. However, it is considered to be synonym of Glomera compressa by Schuiteman and de Vogel (2005).

This species is only known from the type specimen collected in 1875. The species was first described in the genus Peristylus and later transferred to Habenaria (WCSP 2016). However the morphology of the type specimen does not match typical Habenaria and the species could belong in a different genus, possibly Cynorkis or Benthamia (D. Roberts pers. comm. 2016 and V. Boullet pers. comm. 2016). It is also suggested that this species may have a hybrid origin as the type specimen shows morphological characters from two species of Benthamia and two species of Cynorkis (Szelengowicz and Tamon 2013). There are orchid plants found growing on Réunion that are similar to the type specimen of this species (Szelengowicz and Tamon 2013) but further research is required to confirm they are the same species (V. Boullet pers. comm. 2016).

Seidenfaden (1985), Averyanov (1990) and Le Trong Cuc (2005) synonymised Flickingeria unibulbis with F. bancana. The taxon is also synonymised with F. bancana in Wood (2006). Schuiteman and Adams (2011) placed all Flickingeria taxa within Dendrobium, and stated that D. unibulbe was close to D. bancanum but differed in the creeping not erect rhizome. Further taxonomic research is needed, as the question of the relationship between D. unibulbe and D. bancanum is still open to debate (A. Schuiteman pers. comm. 2016). Dendrobium bancana and Flickingeria bancana are not listed as synonyms for this taxon in the World Checklist which is the taxonomy followed in this assessment.

Although given as an accepted name in the World Checklist (WCSP 2016), which is the taxonomy followed in this assessment , this species is similar to the relatively common Dendrobium pruinosum and it is not certain whether some specimens may belong under D. densifolium or D. pruinosum or they may even be synonymous (A. Schuiteman pers. comm. 2016).

Dipodium freycinetoides was first described in 1937 based on two herbarium specimens collected in Palau in 1932 and 1933 (Fukuyama 1937). These two specimens are sterile but in the description of the species it was described as having pale pink flowers. More recent specimens and photos from the Palau and other international herbaria identified as this species were described as having pale yellow flowers, or bright yellow with purple spotted flowers. These are now thought to have been misidentifications and belong to the more widespread species D. fevrellii (P. O'Byrne pers. comm. 2016).

Dipodium freycinetoides and D. fevrellii along with other Dipodium species have very similar leaves so would be difficult to tell apart without flowers. In a revision of Dipodium in preparation by P. O'Byrne, D. freycinetoides is described as "incompletely known" and could possibly be a different colour form of D. fevrellii (P. O'Byrne pers. comm. 2016). If this was confirmed then D. freycinetoides could become a synonym of D. fevrellii (P. O'Byrne pers. comm. 2016). Dipodium freycinetoides does not appear to have been collected since 1932–3 and botanists who have surveyed the Palau flora have only observed Dipodium plants with yellow flowers (A. Kitalong and C. Costion pers. comm. 2016).

The type specimen held at the Herbarium of Berlin was destroyed (Pupulin 2002). Although a low quality image of it is still available at the Harvard University Herbaria, future taxonomic works might be difficult.

A review of the genus Thrixspermum in the Philippine islands Williams (1938) notes, when considering two specimens collected by Vanoverbergh, that they may in reality belong to T. eximium L.Wms and T. integrum L.Wms which were undescribed at the time when Ames published his conclusions.

This species used to be considered very polymorphic and widespread in South America, including up to 20 species names as synonyms (Ames et al. 1934, Schweinfurth 1959, WCSP 2016). However, recent reviews of its taxonomic concept have redefined this species as endemic to Peru characterised by green and white flowers often with purple marks on the disc of the lip and apex of the column (Christenson 2005, Hágsater et al. 2013).

This species is known only from the type specimen which was collected from cultivation. Although it is listed as an accepted name by some authors (Dodson 1992, Missouri Botanical Garden 2016, WCSP 2016), it could also be a synonym or an aberrant form of species (Harding 2008), as there is no record of this species in the wild.

A form growing in Finland has variously been treated as a subspecies (ssp. wahlenbergii) or a full species; the most appropriate taxonomic status needs clarification. The two taxa are recognised here as separate species, in accordance with the World Checklist of Selected Plant Families (RBG Kew 2010).
This species could be the natural hybrid of P. vittatum × P. sargentianum.

Merostachys rondoniensis is an accepted name, but it has been suggested that the taxonomy needs further clarification, particularly to confirm the differences between M. rondoniensis and  M. magnispicula (Sendulsky 1997).
It is difficult to distinguish this species from from C. livingstonii C.B.Clarke, which is widespread in southern Africa, due to unreliable and variable characters.

The taxon is closely related to Othophytum fosterianum. Orthophytum sucrei may be separated from the later by its smaller size, nearly glabrous adaxial leaf surfaces, simple inflorescence, red floral bracts (not green) and pale green petals (not white). Taxonomic uncertainties remain regarding the validity of O. sucrei as an independent species from O. fosterianum (Luther 1997).

This species is only known from the type localities for the two varieties originally described. It has not been collected since these original collections in 1951 and 1952, although it does occur in a well studied region. It is probable that collections have been made but were given different determinations. It is very similar to Aechmea recurvata, which has a wide distribution (M. d'Ávila de Moraes pers. comm. July 2013).
Cyperus boreochrysocephalus from Kenya, Tanzania and Uganda might be a synonym of C. remotus (Hoenselaar et al. 2010).

This is an accepted name. However, the majority of the Borinda / Fargesia species were described for the first time in the 1980s, nearly all from sterile material, and often from a very limited number of collections. Considerable work remains to refine species delimitation, and to relate newly described species to earlier names (Stapleton 1998).

The genus Notylia is in need of revision. No work on its nomenclature has yet been published. The name Notylia inversa is currently accepted but with some associated uncertainty. The taxon may posssibly be a synonym of N. pubescens Lindl. (Nicoletti pers. comm. 2010).

According to Govindarajalu (1974), this species differs from Fimbristylis kingii, another high altitude endemic taxon from the south Indian Hill Stations by, among other features, its annual habit, stems without thickened base, flat acuminate and narrower leaves, smaller ovoid or elliptic-ovoid spikelets and tricostulate nuts with rounded and transversely elongated tubercles. The epithet monospicula is used on the basis that it usually bears a single spikelet at the end of the culm. However, there is some taxonomic uncertainty about the validity of F. monospicula as a species (Prasad pers. comm. 2008).

This species has not been seen since the collection of the type by Ledermann in 1900. In a taxonomic revision of the Calamus species of New Guinea (Baker and Dransfield, in preparation), it is regarded as an unplaced name. Fieldwork within the type locality may clarify the taxonomic status of this taxon.
Malus asiatica Nakai is used as graftstock for cultivated Apple Malus domestica Borkh. (Phipps et al. 1990, USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).
Allium maximowiczii Regel belongs to Taxon Group 2 of Chives A. schoenoprasum L. and Taxon Group 3 of Chinese Scallion A. chinense G.Don (Friesen et al. 2006, Vincent et al. 2013).

The Cape species of Lessertia were last revised by Harvey (1861) in Flora Capensis. He describes Lessertia pappeana from a single collection from Tulbagh. Louisa Bolus includes L. pappeana in her key for the genus (Bolus 1915), however, Goldblatt and Manning (2000) and Manning and Goldblatt (2012) do not include L. pappeana in their conspectus of the Cape Flora. This species is known from only four collections and is suspected to be taxonomically problematic. This genus is urgently in need of revision.

Amygdalus pedunculata Pall. is a synonym of Prunus pedunculata (Pall.) Maxim. This species is secondary genetic relative of Almond (P. dulcis (Mill.) D.A.Webb) and a tertiary genetic relative of Peach (P. persica (L.) Batsch) (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).

Amygdalus mira (Koehne) Ricker is a synonym of Prunus mira Koehne. This species is a primary genetic relative of Peach (Prunus persica (L.) Batsch) and a secondary genetic relative of Almond (Prunus dulcis (Mill.) D.A.Webb) (USDA ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).

Armeniaca mume Siebold is a synonym of Prunus mume Siebold & Zucc.

The species is a secondary genetic relative of Apricot Prunus armeniaca L. (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).

Cerasus dielsiana (C.K.Schneid.) T.T.Yu & C.L.Li is a synonym of the species Prunus dielsiana C.K.Schneid.

This species is a wild relative of cultivated Prunus species, including Sweet Cherry P. avium (L.) L. and Sour Cherry P. cerasus L. (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).
Malus honanensis Rehder is a secondary genetic relative of the cultivated Apple M. domestica Borkh.
Malus kansuensis (Batalin) C.K. Schneid. is a secondary genetic relative of the cultivated Apple M. domestica Borkh.
Malus mandshurica (Maxim.) Kom. ex Juz. belongs to the secondary Gene Pool of cultivated Apple M. domestica Borkh.
Malus ombrophila Hand.-Mazz. belongs to the secondary Gene Pool of cultivated Apple M. domestica Borkh.
Malus orientalis Uglitzk. belongs to the primary Gene Pool of cultivated Apple M. domestica Borkh.
Malus prattii (Hemsl.) C.K.Schneid. belongs to the secondary Gene Pool of cultivated Apple M. domestica Borkh.
Malus prunifolia (Willd.) Borkh. belongs to the secondary Gene Pool of cultivated Apple M. domestica Borkh.
Malus spectabilis (Aiton) Borkh. belongs to the secondary Gene Pool of M. domestica Borkh.
Malus toringoides (Rehder) Hughes belongs to the secondary Gene Pool of cultivated Apple M. domestica Borkh.
Malus transitoria (Batalin) C.K.Schneid. belongs to the secondary Gene Pool of cultivated Apple M. domestica Borkh.
Malus yunnanensis (Franch.) C.K. Schneid. belongs to the secondary Gene Pool of M. domestica Borkh.
Malus zumi (Matsum.) Rehder belongs to the secondary Gene Pool of M. domestica Borkh.

Prunus argentea (Lam.) Rehder belongs to the primary Gene Pool of Almond P. dulcis (Mill.) D.A.Webb and the tertiary Gene Pool of Peach P. persica (L.) Batsch (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).

Prunus domestica is a widely cultivated species. The species is hypothesized to be derived from a hybridisation event between Prunus spinosa and Prunus cerasifolia, however the details of such event is still not fully understood (Horvath et al. 2011).
Prunus ussuriensis Kovalev & Kostina belongs to the primary Gene Pool of Japanese Plum P. salicina Lindl. (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).

Malus chitralensis Vassilczenko is a belongs to the secondary Gene Pool of cultivated Apple M. domestica Borkh. (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).

Some sources suggest that this species is a synonym of M. pumila, (Ignatov and Bodishevskaya 2011) which could explain the lack of information in the literature about this species.
Malus tschonoskii (Maxim.) C.K. Schneid. belongs to the secondary Gene Pool of cultivated Apple M. domestica Borkh.

Prunus bifrons Fritsch belongs to the tertiary Gene Pool of Apricot P. armeniaca L., Almond P. dulcis (Mill.) D.A.Webb, Peach P. persica (L.) Batsch and Japanese Plum P. salicina Lindl. (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).
Prunus bokhariensis Royle ex C.K. Schneid. belongs to the primary Gene Pool of Plum P. domestica L. (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).
Prunus canescens Bois belongs to the tertiary Gene Pool of both Sweet Cherry P. avium (L.) L. and Sour Cherry P. cerasus L. (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).
Prunus concinna Koehne is a genetic relative of Sweet Cherry P. avium (L.) L. having been used as graftstock for this crop (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).

Prunus fenzliana Fritsch belongs to the primary Gene Pool of Almond P. dulcis (Mill.) D.A.Webb and the secondary Gene Pool of Peach P. persica (L.) Batsch (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).
Prunus ferganensis (Kost. & Rjab.) Y.Y.Yao belongs to the secondary Gene Pool of Peach P. persica (L.) Batsch (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).
Prunus incana (Pall.) Batsch is used as graftstock for Peach P. persica (L.) Batsch. (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).
Prunus incisa Thunb. belongs to the tertiary Gene Pool of Sweet Cherry P. avium (L.) L. (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).

Prunus maritima Marshall belongs to the tertiary Gene Pool of cultivated Plum P. domestica L. and is used as graftstock for Peach P. persica (L.) Batsch (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).

Prunus rivularis Scheele belongs to the secondary Gene Pool of Myrobalan Plum P. cerasifera Ehrh. and Japanese Plum P. salicina Lindl.; it has also been used as graftstock for Apricot P. armeniaca and Plum P. domestica L. (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).

This species is considered a synonym of P. munsoniana W.Wight & Hedrick in the Flora of North America (Flora of North America Editorial Committee 2006), however, The Plant List (2013) treats these two taxa as separate species, this is also the case in NatureServe (2013). Here the taxonomy used follows that of The Plant List.

Amygdalus kansuensis (Rehder) Skeels is a synonym of Prunus kansuensis Rehder. This species is a secondary genetic relative of Peach (P. persica (L.) Batsch) and Almond (P. dulcis (Mill.) D. A. Webb) (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).

Armeniaca mandshurica (Maxim.) Skvortsov var. mandshurica (Maxim.) Skvortsov is a synonym of Prunus mandshurica (Maxim.) Koehne.

This species is a secondary genetic relative of Apricot (Prunus armeniaca L.) (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).

Cerasus glandulosa (Thunb.) Sokoloff is a synonym of Prunus glandulosa Thunb.

This species is a tertiary genetic relative of Myrobalan Plum (Prunus cerasifera Ehrh.) and Japanese Plum (Prunus salicina Lindl.) (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).

Cerasus nipponica (Matsum.) H.Ohba is a synonym of Prunus nipponica Matsum.

This species is a secondary genetic relative of Sweet Cherry (Prunus avium (L.) L.) (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).

Cerasus pleiocerasus T.T.Yu & C.L.Li is a synonym of Prunus pleiocerasus Koehne.

This species is a secondary genetic relative of Sweet Cherry (Prunus avium (L.) L.) (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).
Malus muliensis T.C.Ku belongs to the secondary Gene Pool of cultivated apple M. domestica Borkh.
Malus sikkimensis (Wenz.) Koehne belongs to the secondary Gene Pool of cultivated Apple M. domestica Borkh.

In the literature, the spelling of this species' taxonomy varies from Prunus harvardii to Prunus havardii.

It belongs to the secondary Gene Pool of Peach P. persica (L.) Batsch (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).

Also spelt Prunus jacquemontii Hook. f. in the literature, this species belongs to the tertiary Gene Pool of Myrobalan Plum P. cerasifera Ehrh. and Japanese Plum P. salicina Lindl. (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).
Described for the first time by Ashburner and McAllister, 2013.

This species does not appear in the Updated Checklist of the Orchids of Viet Nam (Averyanov and Averyanova 2003) under this name or the homotypic synonym Sayeria neglecta. Averyanov (L.V. Averyanov pers. comm. 2016) considers D. neglectum to be a synonym of Eria dacrydium. The imaged specimens for the syntype of this species from Paris Herbarium were both originally under the name Eria dacrydium Gagnep. D. neglectum is an accepted name within the World Checklist of selected plant families which is the taxonomy followed in this assessment (WCSP 2016).

Further study is required to confirm the correct placement of this species. According to Dimopoulos et al. (2013), Iris falcata Babal. & Papan. is a synonym of Iris attica Boiss. & Heldr (valid name for Iris pumila subsp. attica), whilst Govaerts (2011) consider it an unplaced name.

According to Babalonas and Papanicolaou (1984) Iris falcata is closely related to Iris reichenbachii and Iris suaveolens.

Deschampsia stricta Hack. is considered a synonym of Deschampsia flexuosa (L.) Trin. by eMonocot and WCSP, whilst Euro+Med gives it as a synonym of Avenella flexuosa (L.) Drejer (itself considered a junior synonym of Deschampsia flexuosa by WCSP).

Deschampsia stricta has been included in Portuguese reference floras: Flora de Portugal (Coutinho 1939) and Nova Flora de Portugal-Volume III (Franco and Afonso 1998), although in Flora Europaea it is considered as a synonym of D. flexuosa. More recently, it was listed in the Checklist of Portuguese Flora (ALFA 2010), and considered valid by Romero Zarco & Romero (2009)  (under the name Avenella stricta). This genus has not yet been reviewed by Flora Iberica.

It may be a valid species because the main diagnostic features are consistent (aculeolate leave tops and size of the spikelets) and also occurs in drier habitats than D. flexuosa. But, there is little information on the species, and in the herbarium specimens that have been consulted (A Carapeto pers. comm. 2014) specimens of D. stricta were mixed with D. flexuosa.

Although its validity is uncertain, Deschampsia stricta Hack. is maintained here because even if in fact, it is D. flexuosa, it may be a regional variety adapted to Mediterranean conditions.
There have been no recent taxonomic revisions.
Malus doumeri (Bois) A.Chev. belongs to the tertiary Gene Pool of cultivated Apple M. domestica Borkh. (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).
Malus halliana Koehne belongs to the secondary Gene Pool of cultivated Apple M. domestica Borkh.
Malus toringo (Siebold) Siebold ex de Vriese belongs to the secondary Gene Pool of M. domestica Borkh.
There is some speculation that this species is the result of spontaneous hybridization or introgression in tea gardens (Dongwei Zhao pers. comm. 2015).
It is possible that this species is a synonym of Camellia yunnanensis (Yang pers. comm. 2017).
This species have often been confused with Camellia oleifera and Camellia sasanqua, due to the incomplete original description of the species.
Due to similarities in spelling the species names is sometimes confused with Camellia sinensis.
This species requires allocation to a new genus, probably Polyspora. This combination has yet to be made hence the species is assessed under the name Gordonia ovalis.

Catalogue of life China 2013 Checklist, considers this species a synonym of Polyspora hainanensis. FRPS lists G. balansae sensu Merr et Chun, non Pitard as a synonym but clearly states that P. hainanensis is not the same as Gordonia balansae Pitard (http://frps.eflora.cn/frps/Gordonia%20hainanensis, accessed 9 Dec 2015). Also Polyspora balansae has yellow flowers and is endemic to Viet Nam, whereas P. hainanensis has white flowers and is endemic to Hainan.
Gordonia dipterosperma was named to distinguish Gordonia excelsa var. pubescens. Therefore there is some confusion as this tree has sometimes been called Gordonia excelsa.
This taxon requires further study to determine its status as a species (Luu Hong pers. comm. 2017).

In 1979 Pyrenaria khasiana was described by R.N. Paul based on the collections made in 1867-1871 by Kurz from Khasi Hills, Meghalaya. During botanical exploration (2011–2015) the species was rediscovered and described as a new variety (var. lakhimpurense) (Oduyo and Roy 2017).

authority: (Hu ex Hung T.Chang & C.X.Ye) J.Li & T.L.Ming

taxonomicNotes: This species was first collected by E.H. Wilson in 1907, but the specimens became mixed with specimens of Stewartia sinensis (collected under the same number). In 1998, S. rostrata was described as a variety of S. sinensis by Hung T.Chang. But molecular analysis in 2002 showed that S. rostrata was only distantly related to S. sinensis, and should be considered a species in its own right.
According to Flora of China 2007, the plants referred to as Hartia tonkinensis in Flora Republicae Popularis Sinicae, belong to Stewartia obovata and not S. tonkinensis.
Malus florentina (Zuccagni) C.K.Schneid. is a tertiary wild relative of apple, Malus domestica Borkh (USDA, ARS, GRIN 2018).

Triphora latifolia was thought to be endemic to Florida endemic but the understanding of the taxon expanded when Ackerman (1995) determined vegetative material from Puerto Rico as T. latifolia. In 1995, the distribution of T. latifolia was thought to be Florida, Puerto Rico and Brazil, which is a bit unusual. A careful comparison between T. latifolia and T. amazonica revealed that the only detectable difference between the taxa was the middle lobe of the lip, which may be rounded in T. latifolia or acute in T. amazonica (Ackerman 2000). Triphora amazonica ranges from Brazil to Guyana, French Guiana, Surinam, Trinidad and Dominican Republic, which makes a link with Puerto Rico and Florida. Morphological and geographical information provide evidence that these two taxa are conspecific. Additional specimens are needed to confirm the full geographic extent of T. amazonica sensu lato and that T. amazonica sensu lato is one distinct species throughout its range. The taxonomic treatment followed here indicates that some rare species have much greater range extents than previously thought (Ackerman 2000).

Dioscorea tsaratananensis H.Perrier is a tertiary wild relative of cultivated yams, D. alata L. (Water Yam/Greater Yam), D. bulbifera L. (Aerial Yam), D. cayenensis Lam. (Lagos Yam), D. dumetorum (Kunth) Pax (Bitter Yam), D. esculenta (Lour.) Burkill (Asiatic Yam) and D. rotundata Poir. (White Guinea Yam).

It is still uncertain whether this poorly collected species is really distinct from D. seriflora or whether it is a large form of this species. Molecular data and research is likely to be needed to discover whether they are two distinct species.

This species was originally described as Talauma macrocarpa. It was treated by Standley (1920), Lozano (1994) and Frodin and Govaerts (1996) as a synonym of Magnolia mexicana. In contrast Hemsley (1879), Standley and Steyermark (1946) and most recently Vazquez et al. (2013) have treated them separately.

Camellia hongiaoensis was recently publicized in popular literature under the misapplied name of C. krempfii. However, several morphological discrepancies exist and a new species was therefore described.

This species is only known from the type specimen, Lambert 485, flowering in cultivation at Antananarivo botanic garden (Toilliez-Genoud et al. 1960). A second specimen, Andriamihajarivo 639, collected in 2005 was thought to also be this species but was later redetermined as Aeranthes caudata (Tropicos 2016).
Triticum urartu Tumanian ex Gandilyan is a primary genetic relative of Common Wheat (T. aestivum L.) and Einkorn Wheat (Triticum monococcum L. subsp. monococcum) (USDA, ARS, GRIN 2017).

Festuca paucispicula is considered a synonym of Festuca rubra L. by WCSP (2014).

Al-Bermani et al. (1992) include the species in their circumscription of Festuca trichophylla. Recent observations fully confirm this view, and therefore support its dissociation from Festuca rubra L. (S. Pyke pers. comm. 2015).

Unifying these two grasses in one single species would require a new circumscription which we consider unacceptable at present. Genetic studies might help to resolve this question, but their separation on morphological grounds is easy enough for an agrostologist.

The species is dealt with in its strict sense, adhering to the original description and type material. A similar plant is found in the same region which falls outside these morphological boundaries; this second plant has caused some confusion, and is now being treated as a new species, Festuca dertosensis Pyke and Sáez, (S. Pyke pers. comm. 2015, Pyke et al. 2016).
This species has been treated as a synonym of S. umbellata (e.g., Aldasoro et al. 2004) in the past. A broad taxonomic concept was used in the past and no refined concept has been developed.
Sorbus buekkensis is a relative of Sorbus haszlinszkyana.

This species has only been collected once (in 1949), during a joint excursion made by several botanists in the Keszthely Hills, and it was described based on that collection. No other collections are available and there are no later reliable observations of this species. Further research is required to confirm the status of this species (C. Németh pers. comm. 2016).

There is a cultivar in horticultural trade under the name "S. decipientiformis 'Vállus' ", however, it is not identical with the nominate species, but probably a different apomictic taxon.
The origin of this species is in need of further research as it is thought to be a hybrid (V. Mikolas pers. comm. 2016).
Kovanda (1996) considered the name to be invalidly published as no holotype was assigned.

The species belongs to the S. graeca sensu lato group (A. Sennikov pers. comm. 2016). The species was first described as a forma from the historical region of Transylvania (in present-day Romania) but then raised to species rank and variously interpreted in Hungary, Slovenia and Romania.
This species is considered likely to be a hybrid (S x decipiens). Further research is needed to confirm this (V. Mikolas pers. comm. 2016).
Sorbus latissima is extremely close to Sorbus andreanszkyana and is possibly a synonym (L. Somlyay and A. Sennikov pers. comm. 2016).

Sorbus velebitica is an uncertain taxon that may be part of S. austriaca sensu lato, however S. austriaca has been assessed separately, taking a restricted approach to that taxon. Further study is required to confirm the identity of Sorbus velebitica. Kovanda (1996) considered the name to be invalidly published as no holotype was assigned.
Some authors consider this species as a synonym of Narcissus cantabricus (Castroviejo et al. 2013), however, its recognition as a valid species by Fernandez Casas (2013) is followed here.
A newly described annual species (Romero-Zarco and Arán 2013), it is akin to Juncus tenageia Ehrh. ex L. fil.

Types: Angola, Loanda, Casanga Is., Welwitsch 6982 and Praia do Zamba Grande and Matanga d’el Rei, Welwitsch 7000 and Mocamedes, Cabo Negro, banks of R. Caroca, Welwitsch 6962 (LISU, syn.; BM, isosyn.; drawing of 6982, K).
Dryopteris pseudodisjuncta belongs to the D. affinis group (Fraser-Jenkins 2007), with many closely related species, viz. D. borreri, D. affinis and D. cambrensis.
This species was recently described in Vázquez-García et al. (2015).
This species has been considered under the name Sorbus dacica Borbás for many years until Somlyay and Sennikov (2016) resurrected the name S. semipinnata Borbás.

The only population of Sorbus pelsoensis had been originally identified as S. udvardyana (Bauer 2015). It seems to be little different, if at all, from the latter species (L. Somlyay and A. Sennikov pers. comm. 2016).

This species is not recognised in the revision of Betula by Ashburner and McAllister (2013), and Tarieiev and Heluta (2015) include the species within Betula obscura Kotula ex Fiek., however Betula obscura is itself is treated by some authors as an infrapopulational form (mutation) of Betula pendula; indirect evidence for this opinion is the scattered occurrence of single individuals of Betula obscura within populations of Betula pendula (A. Sennikov pers. comm. 2017). The species requires further research to confirm its taxonomic identity.

This species is considered a synonym of the widespread Betula pubescens Ehrh. by The Plant List (2017), or as a synonym of the widespread B. alba  (Moreno and Peinado 1990, SIVIM 2017) and it has been questioned whether this taxon should be recognized as a distinct species. However, its geographical isolation and the fact that it can be distinguished morphologically suggest that it is worth recognising. In Flora Iberica, Peinado and Mereno (1990) did not distinguish it from Betula alba and this is also stated in López González (2001). However, it is equally out of place in B. pendula. In fact, it is probably most similar to another 'species' of established hybrid origin, the eastern North American B. x caerulea. It is recognized that further research is needed to clarify the status of this species.

Further taxonomic study is required to confirm the separation of S. pseudosemiincia and S. pyricarpa. The two taxa were described from material collected in the same localities, and the morphological difference between the type specimens is unclear.
Sorbus sellii was previously known under the name Sorbus decipiens sensu P.D. Sell. To avoid confusion, Sorbus x decipiens is now used for the primary hybrid between Sorbus aria and S. torminalis.
This species is not well known taxonomically and is not recognised in all regional floras.
The phylogenetic review of Sennikov and Kurtto (2017) placed this species within the new genus Normeyera Sennikov & Kurtto, with other taxa from Sorbus subgen. Chamsoraria Májovský & Bernátová.
This name has commonly been misapplied to Cotoneaster tomentosus (Aiton) Lindl.

This species is considered valid as Malva acerifolia (Cav.) Alef. by Euro+Med Plantbase (Valdés 2011).

Individuals from the eastern Canaries are considered a separate variety (var. hariensis Svent.; S. Scholz pers. comm. 2017).

The taxonomic placement of the species requires further study and has been the subject of much debate. WCSP (2015) considers it (as Iris × mesopotamica Dykes) a synonym of Iris × germanica L., whilst the Flora of Israel Online (Danin and Danin 2015) consider it valid as a species. Further research is needed to confirm if a valid species, a hybrid or cultivar, or a synonym of Iris germanica L.

S. Yuval (pers. comm. 2015) commented that, based on observations of wild populations, it is clearly not a cultivated hybrid, but a natural plant.

Allium panormitanum is quite related to A. cupani, although the two species significantly differ in several features. Firstly, A. panormitanum is a typical autumn-flowering (September-November) geophyte, whereas A. cupani flowers from late spring to summer (June-August). Then, A. panormitanum shows higher stem (20-30 cm), apiculate spathe with 5-9 complete nerves, bigger perigon (c. 8-9 mm) and papillose-rugose ovary, while A. cupani is characterized by a shorter stem (8-20 cm), appendiculate spathe with 3-5 complete plus 2 incomplete lateral nerves, smaller perigon (c. 6-7.5 mm) and entirely smooth ovary” (Brullo et al. 2015).

Quercus acutifolia is a name traditionally assigned to a red oak species, native to America. However, the type specimen corresponds instead to what has been treated in recent works as Q. conspersa, while the type specimen of Q. grahamii Bentham (1840: 57) corresponds to what has been treated as Q. acutifolia (Valencia-A. et al. 2015).

Quercus supranitida was described by C.H. Müller as an endemic species to Nuevo Leon. Both TROPICOS and Valencia-A (2004) consider it a synonym of Q. repanda, but it is accepted by The World Checklist of Selected Plant Families and The Plant List.

Accepted as a species by the World Checklist and Bibliography of Fagales (1998), reduced by Valencia-A. (2004) to a synonym of Quercus ocoteifolia Liebm. (1854), but now accepted by her as distinct and separable from Q. laurina Bonpl. (1809) (Valencia-A et al. 2017).

Heyn and Dafni (1971) rather convincingly demonstrate that the typical Gagea procera, described from Syria, is an autotriploid plant sporadically appearing in the regional populations of a diploid species called “Gagea commutata” and considered them as conspecific.

We agree taxonomically, but not nomenclaturally, with this choice, because Gagea commutata C.Koch is a more northern and continental species very distinct from the Syrian one, at least by its low rate of vegetative multiplication and the complete lack of stipitate sister-bulbs (Levichev 2006). Accordingly, both diploid and triploid plants of “Gagea commutata” sensu auct. Near East are included in Gagea procera here, pending further studies.

Gagea pseudopeduncularis is morphologically very similar from Gagea peduncularis (J.Presl & C.Presl) Pascher and its existence was revealed only by recent molecular analyses (Tison et al. 2013). Subsequently to the latter, some morphological markers have been defined (shorter pedicels, smaller and less acute tepals) but these need to be exploited at the larger scale, especially on the ground.

Described as hybrid (Gagea fibrosa (Desf.) Schult. & Schult.f. × Gagea granatellii (Parl.) Parl.) but the type collections (FI) are unrelated with both putative parental species and close to Gagea dayana Chodat & Beauverd (Peruzzi and Tison 2006).

Taking into account the lack of taxonomic data in the group of G. dayana (see this species) and the disjunct geographic area, Gagea pampaninii is considered as a distinct species pending ontogenic and/or molecular studies.

Romero Rangel (2006) considers Quercus paxtalensis as synonymous with Q. xalapensis Bonpl. Quercus paxtalensis presents fruits of annual maturation, the dome of the acorn is turbinate with the scales somewhat canescentes, the leaves have the base cuneada and occasionally something truncated. Quercus xalapensis has biannual ripening fruits, the dome of the acorn is hemispherical with scales slightly more tomentosa and slightly brown, the leafs of the leaves present the base rounded to obtuse (Mojica and Valencia 2017).

Quercus toxicodendrifolia is listed as a synonym of Q. leiophylla in the World Checklist of Selected Plant Families and The Oak Checklist. But it is an accepted species in TROPICOS, Oaks of the World, and Valencia (2006). According to Valencia et al. (2017) "Quercus toxicodendrifolia Trel. was described from Zacualtipan, Hidalgo in 1924. However in that locality we only found Q. affinis, Q. crassifolia, and Q. lancifolia. The type of Q. toxicodendrifolia recalls Q. lancifolia and it could represent of relatively broad/leaved form of that species."
All analysed individuals showed different CCR patterns. Further research is needed to determine the taxonomy of this species (Gömöry and Krajmerová 2008)
It is thought that this taxon could be similarly taxonomically uncertain as S. haljamovae (see taxonomic note for that species) (V. Mikolas and M. Lepsi pers. comm. 2016).

Molecular, morphological and palynological data all support the recognition of Varronia as a distinct genus from Cordia (Miller and Gottschaling 2007). Hence this species has been moved from Cordia to Varronia.

No new observations nor taxonomic studies have been published since the initial publication of this taxon (Fernández Casas 1999). Nevertheless, further unpublished studies of N. hesperidis specimens performed by Fernández Casas in the two known localities concluded that the subpopulation close to Tafraoute appears to be a chromatic variant of Narcissus peroccidentalis Fern. Casas. (= Narcissus bulbocodium var. kesticus Maire & Wilczek), whose flowers are saturated, homogeneous yellow; the subpopulation corresponding to the species type has a unique leaf cross section within the section Bulbocodii DC., which supports its specific status (F.J. Fernández Casas pers. comm. 2018).

It is treated as a valid species by Govaerts and Kington (Govaerts et al. 2005-2007), then in other taxonomic online databases such as Euro+Med PlantBase (2006-), eMonocot (2013-), Catalogue of Life (Roskov et al. 2018), and the Royal Horticultural Society (RHS 2018). On the contrary, Aedo Pérez (2014) explains that Moroccan members of Narcissus hesperidis section, Sect. Bulbocodium DC., need additional taxonomic investigation and suggests that Narcissus hesperidis may be conspecific of another species.

It is considered as endemic to Morocco by Rankou et al. (2013), but is not cited by Rankou et al. (2015) in their publication about endemic Moroccan Monocotyledons.

Fred Stauffer, Didier Roguet, Mathieu Perret (Conservatory and Botanical Garden of Geneva, Switzerland) and Doudjou Ouattara (University Nangui Abrogua, Côte d'Ivoire), are currently working on the taxonomic revision of the genus Hyphaene.

Current studies on the palm genus Hyphaene (Stauffer and Ouattara 2017) may suggest that Hyphaene macrosperma, longtime regarded as an independant, yet poorly known taxonomic entity, could be rather interpreted as a morphological variant of the widely distributed Hyphaene thebaica.

This is an imperfectly studied taxon almost only known from the original description (Beccari 1908). It is apparently different from all other Hyphaene in its creeping habit, the several arms of the dichotomies radiating outwards from a central point, the stem flattened, tending to lie on the surface of the ground. Additional material is critical for a better understanding of this taxon (Stauffer and Ouattara 2017).

Sorbus zolyomii is a relative of S. hazslinszkyana.

This is part of an unresolved hybrid complex of S. aria sensu lata known from old collections only. The known locality has been revisited but it can not yet be satisfactorily identified in the field (A. Sennikov pers. comm. 2016). Kovanda (1996) considered the name to be invalidly published as no holotype was assigned.
It is considered to be a synonym of Fraxinus insularis by Kang Wang (in litt. June 2017).

As the type was destroyed in the Berlin bombing during World War 2, this is an uncertain taxon  - it is possibly a synonym of Rotala filiformis.
Cicer pinnatifidum Jaub. & Spach is a tertiary genetic relative of Chickpea (Cicer arietinum L.) (Ahmad et al. 2005, USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).
O. longiglumis Jansen is a tertiary genetic relative of rice (O. sativa L.) and African rice (O. glaberrima Steud.) (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2017).
Some taxonomists treat Kyllinga and Cyperus as separate genera, while others treat it as one (Cyperus sensu lato).
Hitchcockella is a monotypic genus.

This taxon is included in a list of Sorbus species described by Kárpáti that are considered to be invalidly published by Kovanda (1996) as no holotype was assigned. A holotype was assigned by C. Németh (2010).

Crataegus sericea is, according to Christensen (1992), a hybrid (C. monogyna × C. orientalis subsp. orientalis).

A. anisochilus is very similar to A. lainzii (which is itself sometimes treated as synonym of A. complicatus subsp. parvifolius) to the extent that Ginés López González (2001) suggests that it should be included as synonymous to it. The Plant List (2016) considers this species to be a subspecies of Adenocarpus complicatus (L.) Gay. However, it is considered as a valid species in Flora Iberica (Castroviejo 1999).
This species is considered "Preliminary Accepted" in Euro+Med (Sennikov 2009).
This species is currently within the genus Angraecum (WCSP 2016). Some scientists consider this species to be part of the genus Humblotiangraecum (Szlachetko et al. 2013).
Allium calamarophilon is taxonomically related to Allium thessalicum and to Allium runemarkii, the latter also known from Evvia.

Physalis angustior Waterf. is a wild relative of Cape Gooseberry, P. peruviana L., Low Ground-cherry, P. pubescens L. and Tomatillo, P. philadelphica Lam. The species is classified in Taxon Group 4, following the definition of Maxted et al. (2006).

Linder (1981) details the close similarities with Disa welwitschii. Disa roeperocharoides can be distinguished from this species by its larger flowers and distinctive petal shape (La Croix and Cribb 1995).

Disa ukingensis Schltr. looks very similar to D. engleriana (Summerhayes 1968, La Croix et al. 1991, La Croix and Cribb 1995). The species is most likely the upland form of Disa engleriana (Lebrun and Stork 2015).

A rare and poorly known species formerly treated as a synonym of Ornithogalum suaveolens (Leighton 1944, Obermeyer 1978). Müller-Doblies and Müller-Doblies (1996), reinstated the species, but with some doubt, and it remains to be resolved. In a recent classification of the Ornithogaloideae (Manning et al. 2009) the species was transferred to the genus Albuca.

Plants from the Vanrhynsdorp area are difficult to distinguish from Antimima watermeyeri (L.Bolus) H.E.K.Hartmann, and more collections and study is needed to assess the taxonomic differences between A. radicans and A. watermeyeri (Klak 2010).

Anisodontea alexandri is a very poorly known species, and its placement within the genus uncertain (Bates 1969). The fragmentary type material makes the evaluation of the validity of this species difficult, and very few other collections have been matched to the description to date. In the Conspectus of the Cape Flora (Goldblatt and Manning 2000), A. alexandri was treated as a synonym of A. biflora., but in Plants of the Greater Cape Region (Manning and Goldblattt 2012) it is recognized as a good species. The genus is in need of revision.

Sennikov pers. comm. 2016). After being treated as an endemic of the Crimea, it was more recently extended to the Caucasus but its distribution there is not well studied and in fact the identity of such plants should still be confirmed.

This species is known only from two rather small specimens. Philcox (1990: 127) noted "both collections are incomplete and likewise imperfect but there are enough characters of Last s.n.  for me to tentatively agree with Skan that it is probably distinct. Correspondingly Cecil 257 shows enough similarities to ally it to the other". That said, the Cecil specimen has a considerably more lax inflorescence than the Last specimen (I. Darbyshire, pers. obs.), and is also recorded from a different habitat, being from swamps in the coastal lowlands at Dondo whilst the Last specimen is from Mt Namuli.

Coffea andrambovatensis J.-F.Leroy is a wild relative of commercial coffee species, C. arabica L. and C. canephora Pierre ex A.Froehner (Vincent et al. 2013). The species is classified in Gene Pool 3 for both species, following the definition of Maxted et al. (2006).
Coffea fragilis J.-F.Leroy is a wild relative of commercial coffee, C. arabica L. (Vincent et al. 2013). The species is classified in Gene Pool 3, following the definition of Maxted et al. (2006).

Physalis porrecta Waterf. is a wild relative of Cape Gooseberry, P. peruviana L., Low Ground-cherry, P. pubescens L. and Tomatillo, P. philadelphica Lam. The species is classified in Taxon Group 4, following the definition of Maxted et al. (2006).
Persea sessilis Standl. & Steyerm. is a wild relative of avocado, P. americana Mill. The species is classified in Taxon Group 4, following the definition of Maxted et al. (2006).

The taxonomic status of Dracaena bueana Engl. is not yet resolved. J. J. Bos, the authority on the genus, had no knowledge of this plant until 1984, when Leeuwenburg brought a specimen from Ghana, which at that time was judged to be be either D. fragrans or D. arborea: they cannot be distinguished when sterile. Eventually it flowered and Bos identified it as D. bueana Engl.  Its reproductive characters are intermediate between the two tree species mentioned above, and it may be of hybrid origin, however, the plant is fertile, and produces fruits.

Chlorophytum caudatibracteatum is known only from the type collection in 1909. In a recent flora of the Chlorophytum species from Cameroon this species was noted as uncertain, as the collection came from a young plant, but does not match any of the currently accepted species in the genus (Bjorå and Nordal 2014).

Cenchrus massaicus (Stapf) Morrone is a wild relative of Pearl Millet Cenchrus americanus (L.) Morrone (syn. Pennisetum glaucum (L.) Br.). The species is classified in Taxon Group 4, following the definition of Maxted et al. (2006).

Laccosperma cristalensis has been described in 2016 by Couvreur and Niangadouma (2016).

It closely resembles Laccosperma korupensis by the absence (or near absence) of acanthophylls on the cirrus (extension of the leaf rachis). These are the only two species of African rattans to share this character. However, L. cristalensis is easily distinguished from L. korupensis by having fewer pinnae (5-8 versus 10-18) which are sigmoid versus lanceolate, lacking spines along the margin versus presence of spines along the margin and an ocrea that is 3-5 mm long and truncated versus 7-10 cm long and tapering to a point (Sunderland 2012).

Two varieties were previously recognised; Juncus valvatus var. echinuloides (Brot.) Coss.(Portugal) and var. caricinus Coss. & Dur. (North Africa). According to Le Floc’h et al. (2010) these varieties are no longer recognised.
Berlinia sapinii is a poorly known species and may be conspecific with B. lundensis, however, Mackinder and Pennington treat it as a separate species in their monograph of the genus (2011).
Future studies are required to more accurately define its taxonomic boundaries.
O. coarctata Roxb. is a tertiary wild relative of rice (O. sativa L.) and African rice (O. glaberrima Steud.).
O. glumipatula Steud is a primary wild relative of rice (O. sativa L.) and African rice (O. glaberrima Steud.).
Oryza schweinfurthiana Prodoehl is a  secondary wild relative of cultivated rice (O. sativa L.) and African rice (O. glaberrima Steud.; USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2017).
Narcissus jonquilla is one of a complex of species that require further taxonomic clarification.
Cenchrus squamulatus (Fresen.) Morrone belongs to the secondary Gene Pool of Pearl Millet Cenchrus americanus (L.) Morrone [= Pennisetum glaucum (L.) R.Br.].
We follow Euro+Med Plantbase (Kurtto 2009) for this taxon. Malus dasyphylla Borkh. is a wild relative of apple, Malus domestica Borkh.

Sorbus teodori is not accepted as a valid species by many taxonomists, and will be included as a heterotypic synonym to Sorbus meinichii in the forthcoming volume of Flora Nordica.

Based on current species concepts in the study of this genus (Rich et al. 2010) it would be arguable to keep a Baltic narrow endemic Sorbus teodori and a Norwegian endemic S. meinichii. However, if following this approach, several clonal variations observed might require taxonomic recognition, increasing the number of narrow endemic Sorbus spp. in Fennoscandia. The more traditional Linnaean species concept would include all those varieties in Sorbus meinichii. Taxonomic studies of the genus in northern Europe are underway, for example by the Arboretum and Botanical Garden of the University of Bergen (P.H. Salvesen pers. comm. 2010, Artsdatabanken 2010).

According to the latest Swedish Red List (ArtDatabanken 2015), S. teodorii (Swedish) is triploid and S. meinichii (Norwegian) is tetraploid and therefore both names should be retained. Unpublished results on the ploidy levels of these taxa show that the situation is more complicated, with several triploid populations occurring in Norway, and also a number of tetraploid populations as well (P.H. Salvesen pers. comm. 2016). Thus in addition to allowing the two names to be retained in the strict sense, there is probably a need for defining new species within the complex, both in Norway and Sweden, and possibly also in Finland.

Schuiteman and De Vogel (2003) note that Vermeulen examined the type of Phreatia globulosa and found that it was not a Phreatia but undoubtedly a Bulbophyllum species of sect. Lepanthanthe (Vermeulen 1993). However, the type material has no flowers and is similar to two other Bulbophyllums. It was concluded that an unambiguous interpretation of the type specimen was not possible, although it may be in the future, if more material is found or genetic analysis undertaken.
The type specimen has been lost and it is now known only from the original description and drawings and the colour is not recorded (de Vogel et al. 2018).

Bulbophyllum inquirendum is a dubious entity. It is possible that it is a species showing excessive variability in the shape of the lip, but it is possible that it has hybrid origin with B. crutwellii and B. lepanthiflorum as parents. More information is needed, which is why the name 'inquirendum' was chosen (Vermeulen 1993).
In the Orchids of New Guinea online (De Vogel et al. 2018) and also in Schlecter's Orchidaceae novae et criticae (Schlecter 1921) it is under the name Bulbophyllum stenorhopalos.

This orchid was very inadequately described as Dendrobium taurinum Lindl. var. amboinense by Rolfe in 1897 (Ormerod 2009). Cribb (1986) found no trace of a preserved specimen at Kew but thought that in flower colour it seemed possibly attributable to D. odoardii rather than D. taurinum. It was described as a new species, D. burkeanum, by Ormerod in 2009.
The description of this species was based on two cultivated specimens and the possibility that it is of hybrid origin cannot be ruled out (Cribb 1986).
Dendrobium euryanthum is closely allied to Dendrobium punamense and to the even more similar Dendrobium armeniacum (Cribb 1983, De Vogel et al. 2018)

Ormerod (2009) notes that this orchid is closely related to Dendrobium tangerinum Cribb but so far has only been found growing as a lithophyte at higher altitudes than D.tangerinum which is an epiphyte in lower altitude areas. Cribb (1983) included both of the collections cited by Ormerod (2009) for D.fornax under D.tangerinum and noted that D.tangerinum was epiphytic or rarely lithophytic.

This species has an obscure callus only and a prominent callus is a feature of sect. Latouria species and it may be that this species is based on an abnormal, possibly somewhat peloric specimen. It is closely related to the Moluccan species D. laurensii  and may represent a variant of that or a closely allied species (Cribb 1983).

This is a very imperfectly known species, not included in the key to the species of section Spatulata (Cribb 1986). It should be compared with Dendrobium odoardii and will have priority over that name if it is proved to be conspecific (De Vogel et al. 2018).

Prunus discolor is a wild relative of Almond, P. dulcis (Mill.) D.A.Webb, Peach and Nectarine, P. persica (L.) Batsch, Plum, P. domestica L., Sloe, P. spinosa L. and Sweet Cherry, P. avium (L.) L.

This assessment only considers the wild population and the native range of the species.

Prunus tenella Batsch is a wild relative of Almond, P. dulcis (Mill.) D.A.Webb, Peach and Nectarine, P. persica (L.) Batsch, Plum, P. domestica L., Sloe, P. spinosa L. and Sweet Cherry, P. avium (L.) L.

Pyrus nivalis Jacq. is a wild relative and progenior of Pear, P. communis L. subsp. communis. On USDA, ARS, GRIN (2018) the species is treated as a hybrid however it is an accepted name on IPNI and Kews' PlantList. Therefore the species is fully assessed here.
This assessment also considered the Pyrus nivalis subsp. orientalis.

There is a low level of separation of Fraxinus pallisiae from other forms of F. angustifolia, and the species is often considered a synonym of the very widespread F. angustifolia (FRAXIGEN 2005), although some eastern European botanists maintain them as separate taxa, and they are currently maintained as such taxa by The Plant List (2017).

Prunus brigantina Vill. is a wild relative of almond, P. dulcis (Mill.) D.A. Webb, peach and nectarine, P. persica (L.) Batsch, plum, P. domestica L., sloe, P. spinosa L. and sweet cherry, P. avium (L.) L.

Hunt et al. (2006) include E. uyupampensis (Backeb) H.Friedrich & G.D.Rowley as a doubtful synonym of E. glauca. The former is endemic to Arequipa and morphologically very different. The taxonomy should be revised and the assessment updated as soon as possible.

There is uncertainty about the validity of this species. It could be C. imbricata (Haw) Knuth or a form of C. tunicata (Lehm) Knuth with a different flower colour which is deep pink, this form is described by Rose as C. pallida (Rose) Knuth (Hunt et al. 2006).
Coryphantha retusa is difficult to distinguish from Corphantha pycnacantha as well as other species in the genus.
The taxonomy of this species is confusing, as it includes subspecies that are morphologically very different, which probably represent separate species. A taxonomic revision is needed.
B. columnaris is recognized as a good species by Hunt et al. (2006), but Arakaki et al. (2006) believe that the taxonomic status requires re-evaluation.
Two subspecies are recognized, the nominate and subsp. icaensis (F.Ritter) D.R.Hunt; these are not assessed separately here.
Echinopsis chamacereus was described at the beginning of the 20th Century, but it was never found again (R. Kiesling pers. comm. 2012).
Two subspecies are recognized, the nominate and subsp. koehresianus (G.Frank) W.Rischer & G.Frank.
The taxonomy of C. squarrosus is confusing. Most likely, the specimens described as C. squarrosus that are distant from the type locality belong to different species. A revision is urgently needed.
A taxonomic revision of this taxon is needed, as the  subpopulations in Moquegua and Tacna are morphologically different from  the one in Arequipa and probably represent a different species.
Hunt et al. (2006) say that this taxon is doubtfully distinct from C. morawetzianus Backeb.
There are several synonyms for this species, which other researchers consider to be separate species. The taxonomy should be revised.
Further research is needed to determine whether this species is distinct from D. nudiflorus
Treated by Blum et al. (1998) as a subspecies of E. longisetus. Taylor (1985) treated it as a variety of E. delaetii, but Hunt et al. (2006) treat it as a good species.
Two subspecies are recognized, the nominate form and subsp. ochoterenae (J.G.Ortega) N.P.Taylor.

A. dinae, A. multiflora, A. eriocaulis and A. beateae are a group of clearly distinct but related species occurring in Minas Gerais and Bahia. In the past some authors regarded them as conspecific under the oldest name A. dinae. Recent studies and better knowledge in the field, however, show that it is better to maintain these taxa at the rank of separate species. In some cases they even grow together (A. dinae, A. eriocaulis) without hybridization (P. Braun pers. comm. 2012).
Hunt et al. (2006) placed this species into synonymy under Cleistocactus buchtienii whilst others treat it as being synonymous with C. palhuayensis F.Ritter & Shahori.

Hunt et al. (2006) treat this taxon as being synonymous with Consolea macracantha (Griseb). A.Berger. The Plant List on the other hand has it as a synonym of C. moniliformis (L.) A.Berger.

The name Opuntia picardae, was published as a replacement name for O. microcarpa K.Schum in the mistaken belief that the latter was a later homonym (see Hunt et al. 2006).

Accepted as a species by Anderson (2001) and Pilbeam (1999). Lüthy (1995) and the Assessors consider it to have been a synonym of M. jaliscana (Britton & Rose) Boed. / M. mercadensis Patoni. The description of this plant does not differentiate it from M. jaliscana / M. mercadensis Patoni, found in the Durango area and widely elsewhere. Hunt et al. (2006) indicate that its status is uncertain and that it is perhaps just a form of M. jaliscana.

Considered synonymous with M. crinita by Anderson (2001) and synonymous with M. crinita ssp. crinita by Pilbeam (1999) and by the Assessors. It is accepted as a good species by Hunt et al. (2006). The Assessors have demonstrated that the M. painteri description lists no characteristics that differentiate it from the surrounding M. crinita ssp. crinita apart from noting that the axils are naked, a characteristic often found in individuals within M. crinita ssp. crinita populations.
Hunt et al. (2006) treats this as a provisional species, but it is possible that it is conspecific with Mammillaria albilanata.
Three subspecies are recognized, the nominate subspecies, subspecies pilcayensis (Bravo) D.R.Hunt and subspecies tepoxtlana D.R.Hunt.
Two subspecies are recognized, the nominate form and subsp. onychancanthus (F.Ritter) N.P.Taylor.

authority: (Salm-Dyck ex DC.) Britton & Rose ex Bail.
taxonomicNotes: No taxonomic issues.
The taxonomic status of this taxon is uncertain, it is close to M. uncinata and M. heyderi.
Some people consider this species to be conspecific with M. heyderi.
Two subspecies are recognized, the nominate subspecies and subspecies bambusiphila (Repp.) D.R.Hunt.
Two subspecies are recognized, the nominate subspecies and subspecies apamensis (Repp.) D.R.Hunt.

Considered a synonym of M. mercadensis by cactus specialist Anderson (2001) and by the assessors. Provisionally accepted as a species by cactus specialists, Hunt (1999) and Pilbeam (1999). This assessment is based on the populations in the areas identified as M. sinistrohamata by Pilbeam. The assessors find no characteristics in the description that differentiate it from M. mercadensis. The counterclockwise orientation of the hooks on the central spines, that is the basis of the epithet, appears irregularly as it does in other M. mercadensis subpopulations. The yellow spines and flowers appear also in M. mercadensis (Hunt 1987 re M. sinistrohamata).
Treated by Craig as synonymus with M. mammillaris, but differing in spination, distant from other known sites of that species and probably more closely related to M. nivosa (Hunt et. al 2006),
Treated by some as a variant of M. melanocentra, but has been provisionally accepted as a good species pending further field study; it also has some features of M. gigantea (Hunt et al. 2006).
This species is possibly a dwarf form of M. lemairei (Hunt et al. 2006).

Undocumented plants in cultivation under this name appear to be a form of M. parkinsonii Ehrenb. whereas plants collected from the wild in recent years appear to be a form of M. hahniana Werdem. (Hunt et al. 2006). Some experts consider this to be a synonym of M. parkinsonii (R. Bárcenas pers. comm. 2010; Guzmán et al. 2003). Further research is needed on the taxonomy of this group.
Has two subspecies, the nominate and subsp. ernestii (Fittkau) Glass & R.A.Foster. These are included in the current assessment, i.e. they are not assessed separately.

This species is closely allied to M. petterssonii and allied taxa from Durango, Jalisco and Zacatecas. W.A. Fitz Maurice (pers. comm. 2009) argues that plants at the type locality are all M. pettersonii.

This taxon is most likely conspecific with N. conoidea (DC.) Britton & Rose, plants with the same characteristics of N. matehualensis appear in M. conoidea subpopulations (H. Hernández., W.A. Fitz Maurice and B. Fitz Maurice pers. comm. 2009).

This species was treated tentatively under Nopalea auberi by Hunt et al. (2006), but is treated here as a good species. N. guatamalensis is also tentatively included here. This is in fact the older name, hence if it is included here, the nomenclature for this taxon needs further consideration.
This species is not well-defined and can be easily confused with other species with in the genus. It is part of a species complex.
No taxonomic issues.
Bauer (2002) recognizes this as a good species, however, the country-specialist considers it to be a synonym of P. himantoclada (B. Hammel pers. comm. 2009).
This species is often confused with S. grandiflorus.  There is disagreement about the validity and identification of this species. There are few herbarium records for this species.
The genus Stenocactus is in need of taxonomic revision.

It is thought that the original locality of the species is under water in the Zimapán dam. The Cadereyta Regional Botanical Garden has wild and cultivated specimens (E. Sánchez pers. comm. 2011). There are some subpopulations left in the surrounding areas of the dam (Ortega-Varela 2004).
This species may be a form of Opuntia anacantha or young specimens of Brasiliopuntia sp. (Leuenberger 2002).

Hunt et al. (2006) consider it as a synonym of  O. eliator. Anderson 2001 considers it distinct. For this assessment it is considered as a distinct species (L. Majure and P. Griffith pers. comm 2011).

The species is recognized as a provisional taxon by Hunt et al. (2006). Expert R. Kiesling (pers. comm. 2012) does not recognize it as a good species but as part of Tunilla corrugata and argues that T. microdisca was described from cultivated plants and its origin is unknown and it holds the characters of T. corrugata.
Bauer (2003) placed this species in Epiphyllum.

This species is very poorly known and the taxonomy is dubious. Morphologically very similar to other members of the genus and thus there is no clear definition of where the limits are between this and surrounding Stenocereus species (S. Arias pers. comm. 2009)
This species is a sister species of S. grandiflorus, and it may not be a separate species (S. Arias pers. comm. 2009).
This species may include P. estevesii and P. goianus.

The validity of this species is questionable and further information is needed on the relationship between this taxon and O. leucotricha (and other similar species) so that the limits of its distribution and population size can be defined.

The species is recognized as a provisional taxon by Hunt et al. (2006). Expert R. Kiesling (pers. comm. 2012) does not recognize it as a good species but as part of Tunilla corrugata and argues that T. erectoclada was described from cultivated plants and its origin is unknown and it holds the characters of T. corrugata.

Some authors treat this as a subspecies: Opuntia engelmannii subsp. aciculata (Griffiths) U.Guzmán & Mandujano, however, it is treated here as a good species following Hunt et al. (2006) and Pinkava 2003. The origin of this species is uncertain.
Three subspecies are recognized, the nominate form, subsp. albiflora (F.Ritter & Buining) Hjertson and subsp. perplexa (Donald) Hjertson.
This species is not well-defined taxonomically. It can easily be confused with other species in its genus.
Arias and Terrazas (2009) place this species in the genus Lophocereus.

This species was described by Britton and Harris in 1911.  This species is listed as potentially synonymous of O. tuna by Hunt et al. 2006.  Adams (1972) reports both O. tuna and O. jamaicensis for Jamaica, but they are not sympatric in the wild.  O. tuna, however, is widely cultivated.
This species is considered by some to be a synonym of Clesitocactus smaragdiflorus (M. Lowry pers. comm. 2012). Others indicate that it may be conspecific with C. parviflorus (K.Schum.) Rol.-Goss.
This species cannot be assigned to a species group with confidence on present knowledge (Hunt et al. 2006).
This name is not included in The New Cactus Lexicon (Hunt et al. 2006). It is recognised as a good species by Anderson (2001). It appears in Butterworth's new Cactaceae list published on ITIS.
Cette espèce est peut-être une synonyme de Coccothrinax argentea (Henderson et al. 1995) mais il faut faire les analyses génétiques pour le vérifier.
According to Dimopoulos et al. (2013) this taxon is probably of hybrid origin, derived from C. avellana under cultivation.

Romulea battandieri Bég. is considered a synonym of the widespread Romulea columnae Sebast. & Mauri by WCSP (2017), however participating experts at the North Africa monocotyledon assessment review workshop (Rabat, 2016) did not agree with WCSP and considered this a valid species following Maire (1959) and Dobignard and Chatelain (2010).
Gensita parnassica is possibly not specifically distinct from G. salzmanii (Gibbs 1966).
This species is reinstated in Thomson and Braglia (2017) where it is seen to be 'well marked morphologically and genetically distinct from Hibiscus rosa-sinensis'.

The genus Licania, which is confined to the Neotropics, is highly polyphyletic in molecular phylogenetic analyses. These studies show that the three subgenera of Licania, as well as sections within them, are not supported as monophyletic. Sothers et al. (2016) have re-delimited the genus using a molecular phylogenetic analysis as a framework and placed the former Lincania species under eight genera, namely Licania, Moquilea, Leptobalanus, Hymenopus, Microdesmia, Parinariopsis, Geobalanus and Cordillera.

Although only partially sampled, initial results of molecular phylogenetic sampling of African Podostemaceae have convincingly shown that Ledermanniella subg. Phyllosoma forms a well-supported clade of species that are sister to the rest of all other African Podostemaceae sampled. Inversodicraea has therefore been resurrected to accommodate those species previously included in Ledermanniella subg. Phyllosoma (see Cheek et al. 2017 for further details).
The taxonomic identity of this species requires confirmation and a revision is in progress (F. Bogunić pers. comm. 2017).
As with Terminalia hararensis, this species may by synonymous with T. polycarpa but this requires confirmation.
Persea purpusii L.E. Kopp is a wild relative of avocado, P. americana Mill. The species is classified in Taxon Group 4, following the definition of Maxted et al. (2006).
Persea veraguasensis Seem. is a wild relative of avocado, P. americana Mill. The species is classified in Taxon Group 4, following the definition of Maxted et al. (2006).
A taxonomically dubious species. It may become synonymous with Terminalia polycarpa or T. prunioides.

We are assessing this species in the narrow sense. This species is sometimes considered a synonym of Commiphora hildebrantii however C. hildebrantii is also considered a synonym of this taxon. We have treated them as separate species as we consider them to be different. However further taxonomic work is need to confirm this.

This is a species complex and is not well typified.

This is a species complex; collections from Thailand and Indonesia are known as Wurfbainia testaca and W. compactum.
